for children, and your weight would probably break it.  You acn get
back on the park path to the west or travel on an ornate road to
the north.

224.name: An Ornate Road
desc: "   You can't get over how beautiful the road is.  You tread lightly so
that your books won't scuff or mar the surface.  It seems as if the
road is leading you away from the park and towards a residential section
of town.  The road goes to the east and the north.

225.name: An Ornate Road
desc: "  Small lanterns line the side of the road here.  Evidently, they're
lit when it's dark to provide a soft light to walk by.  How considerate.
The path leads both north and south.

226.name: Outside Midgard Estates
desc: "  The ornate path comes to an end at a huge pair of steel gates.  The
metal has been polished to a beautiful sheen.  The gates stand closed
and locked.  There's a small sign on the front.

227.name: The Clerics Inner Sanctum
desc: "   Welcome, Cleric, to the Inner Sanctum.  Only followers of the One true
faith have been allowed to progress this far.  The Cross of Virtue, symbol
of your faith, has been carved into the stone in the center of the room.
Small oil lamps provide just enough light to see by...no more.  The only
exit is to the east.

228.name: The Circle of Meditation
desc: "   Unlike the entrance to the guild, the Meditation Circle lacks any
kind of decoration.  In the center of the room, the Warriors Cross rises
a full eight feet into the air.  At the base of the cross the image of
crossed swords has been carved into the stone.  The only exit leads
back to the guild.

229.name: The Druids Inner Sanctum
desc: "   The network of roots from the plants overhead prevent the surrounding
soil from crashing in around you.  Hovering in the center of the room
is the Seed of Life.  Legend has it that when man and nature finally
live in harmony, the Seed of Life will sprout and grow.  It's this cause
that the Druids work toward.  The only exit leads up back to the guild.

230.name: The Rangers Lair
desc: Odd that you'd find a Lair in the attic of the guild...
Glancing around, you notice that the room is void of any kind of decoration.
In one corner, the bones of various sorts of creatures lie neatly stacked.

231.name: The Bards' Conservatorium
desc: "   A man sits here playing the most beautiful music you've ever heard.
You can do nothing but stand enraptured as he finishes his song.  The
tears roll down your face unchecked...he can only be your Guildmaster.

232.name: The Amber Rose Dining Hall
desc: "  The dining hall of the Amber Rose takes your breath away.  The entire
east and south walls are made of a crystal clear glass.  Through the
huge windows, you see the Inverness river snaking its way through the
country side.  An enormace smokey quartz chandelier casts mysterious
shadows across the room.

233.name: The Barbarians' Practice Field
desc: "   A field of waving grass stretches out in all directions as far as the
eye can see.  It's an illusion, of course, but it still brings back
memories of the barbarian way of life before this...city.  The only
thing in the field besides youself is your guildmaster.

234.name: The Sanctorum of the Caviler
desc: "  The Sanctorum is made completely of the finest granite.  All four of
the walls are completely blank save for a simply cross.  Here, the true
Caviler prays that his honor remain as unshakeable as the granite walls.
The only exit leads back to the Guild Hall.

235.name: The Ninjas' Lair
desc: "   Fine willow paneling covers the four walls of this room.  Except
for a simple floormat, this room is devoid of any decoration or furnature.
This is where you'll learn the habits of a true Ninja.  The only
exit is to the north.

236.name: The Meeting Hall
desc: "  This large room is filled with a comfortable light, allowed to fall in
from the circle-shaped ceiling window.  Two massive oak tables stand in
the center of the room, numerous wooden chairs standing along their sides,
allowing perhaps five people to sit down at once.  A fireplace has been
constructed at the northern wall, a piece of beautiful craftwork.  The grey
stone walls have been literally covered with paintings and weapon shields,
showing both glorious victories and horrible defeats.  Dozens of
candlesticks stand upon the oak tables, providing light for the hall during
night-time.  The hallway lies to the south.
"  Two half circles, one in pale green glass, and one in pale blue have been
merged together into an ceiling window. An opening device has been
nailed to the western wall, allowing one to open and close the window from
below.
"  Dull grey metal candlesticks, they seem quite heavy for their size.
Along each table, five candlesticks have been placed, providing light when
needed.

237.name: The Secret Yard
desc: "  There doesn't seem to be anything down here except the foundation...
and your Guildmaster.  Although you see no-one else around, instinct
tells you that they eyes of the Guild are watching.  The only exit leads
up back to the abandoned building.

238.name: The Magic-Users' Laboratory
desc: "   A huge kettle of boiling...whatever...rests in the center of the room.
Runes of warding and protection cover every inch of the walls, ceiling,
and floor in preparation for the powerful magic often performed in this
room.  The only exit leads south to the guild entrance.

239.name: Floating Through the Ether
desc: "   In a flash of light, the Quick-Go Booth once again transfers you
through space.  The loss of sensation when in the Ether has always
seemed eerie to you. Luckily, it'll be over soon.

240.name: Floating Through the Ether
desc: "   In a flash of light, the Quick-Go Booth once again transfers you
through space.  The loss of sensation when in the Ether has always
seemed eerie to you. Luckily, it'll be over soon.

241.name: Floating Through the Ether
desc: "   In a flash of light, the Quick-Go Booth once again transfers you
through space.  The loss of sensation when in the Ether has always
seemed eerie to you. Luckily, it'll be over soon.

242.name: Floating Through the Ether
desc: "   In a flash of light, the Quick-Go Booth once again transfers you
through space.  The loss of sensation when in the Ether has always
seemed eerie to you. Luckily, it'll be over soon.

243.name: The Illusionists' Parlor
desc: "  The walls here swim in and out of existance.  You're not sure what's
supporting you, but the fact that you're not falling is somehow reassuring.
Although you can't see it, you're positive that an exit on the west wall
will take you back the way you came.

244.name: The Avengers' Prayer Circle
desc: "   Here, the Avenger prays to the forces of evil to grant him to power to
carry out their bidding.  The room is completely empty save for a few
sharp instruments used to draw blood in sacrifice.  The only exit leads
up.

245.name: The Secret Library
desc: "   An enormace library has somehow been smuggled into the basement of
the Guild.  You have no doubt that the black bound books contain the
Guild secrets on killing quickly and efficiently.  A trap door in the
ceiling leads back to the Guild.

246.name: Inside the West Gate of Midgard
desc: "   The city walls stretch away to the north and south, protecting the
people of Midgard from invading hoards.  Just a few steps west, and
you'll be outside the city proper and at the mercy of the world beyond.
To the east, you see the intersection of Main Street and The Iron Road.

247.name: Outside the West Gate of Midgard
desc: "   You are standing outside the city gate.  The gates are partially shut,
keeping out the strong wind of the plains from sweeping through the city.
The great city wall stretches to the north and south.  Looking outward
from the city there lies the great plain, leading to the great plains and
forests to the west of the city.  The road looks very dusty, making your
mouth dry and parched at sight of it.

248.name: Inside the East Gate of Midgard
desc: "   Two huge towers here support a massive wooden gate.  In case of an
attack on the city, the gate would be the only thing standing between
the people of Midgard and total destruction.  Main Street stretches
out to the west while the outside world is to the east.

249.name: Outside the East Gate of Midgard
desc: "   One more step east and you'll leave the privacy and comfort of Midgard
behind.  Of course, you could always change your mind and go back to
the west...back to Main Street.  It's your decision though.

250.name: North End of the Shrine of Neutrality
desc: "   As you walk under the Portal of Spirituality, you get a good look at
the rest of the Shrine.  Fifty-six sandstone colums are equally spaced
to form a circle almost a quarter of a mile in diameter.  The columns
at the north, south, east and west are slightly larger to support a
cross block, which forms the portal you just passed through.  A dirt
path to the south leads to a stone altar in the center of the circle.

251.name: The Altar of Symmetry
desc: "   In the heart of the Shrine of Neutrality lies the Altar of Symmetry.
This is where those whose lives are guided by the precepts of Neutrality
come to sacrifice.  The Altar is constructed of equal proportions of
white marble, grey granite and black obsidian.  Exits lead off in all
directions to the edges of the Shrine.

252.name: West End of the Shrine of Neutrality
desc: "   As you walk under the Portal of the Setting Sun, you get a good look at
the rest of the Shrine.  Fifty-six sandstone colums are equally spaced
to form a circle almost a quarter of a mile in diameter.  The columns
at the north, south, east and west are slightly larger to support a
cross block, which forms the portal you just passed through.  A dirt
path to the east leads to a stone altar in the center of the circle.

253.name: South End of the Shrine of Neutrality
desc: "   As you walk under the Portal of Rebellion, you get a good look at
the rest of the Shrine.  Fifty-six sandstone colums are equally spaced
to form a circle almost a quarter of a mile in diameter.  The columns
at the north, south, east and west are slightly larger to support a
cross block, which forms the portal you just passed through.  A dirt
path to the north leads to a stone altar in the center of the circle.

254.name: East End of the Shrine of Neutrality
desc: "   As you walk under the Portal of the Rising Sun, you get a good look at
the rest of the Shrine.  Fifty-six sandstone colums are equally spaced
to form a circle almost a quarter of a mile in diameter.  The columns
at the north, south, east and west are slightly larger to support a
cross block, which forms the portal you just passed through.  A dirt
path to the west leads to a stone altar in the center of the circle.

255.name: The Ante-Chamber to The Cathedral of Virtue
desc: "   The power of goodness seems to exude out of the soft ivory paneling
filling you with an inner strength.  No many how many times you enter
this room, you never get over the feeling.  Just north of here, tow
huge golden doors open to the main hall of the Cathedral.  Hesitantly,
you notice that Woodmar Lane begins its journey south beyond the
wooden doors of the Cathedral.

256.name: The Cathedral of Virtue
desc: "   The air here is pure and almost sings with the glory of virtue!  Marble
walls soar hundreds of feet in the air to support the barely visible
ceiling.  Intricately carved statues depict the Gods and Goddesses of
good in all their glory.  A bit to the north, the Alter of Spirituality
pulses in a holy light.  The ante-chamber lies to the south, while two
small acloves line the east and west walls.

257.name: The Altar of Spirituality
desc: "   The Altar of Spirituality stands before you, burning with the light of
one-thousand suns.  The holy light fills you with excitement in your
worship to the glory of goodness.  Here, pilgrims from across the land
come to sacrifice in the name of Virtue.  The only exit from this glorius
site leads back to the center of the Cathedral.

258.name: An Aclove West of the Cathedral
desc: A smaller altar rests in this portion of the Cathedral for modest
sacrifices and for the confession of sin.  Elaborate frescos telling
the stories of the Gods of Virtue decorate the walls.  An exit to
the east leads back to the main Cathedral.

259.name: An Aclove East of the Cathedral
desc: "   A small spring of holy water bubbles in a small pool set into the
floor.  A few coins have been left at the bottom of the pool as a
sacrifice to the Gods.  The walls are decorated with small frescos detailing
the eventual victory over evil.  The only exit leads back to the main
Cathedral.

260.name: The Ante-Chamber to The Cathedral of Corruption
desc: "   The obsidian walls exude the power of evil as they climb toward the
ceiling.  Being this close to the main room of the Cathedral fills
you with excitement.  The power of evil is much stronger than that
of good, and you can feel it pulsing within your veins.
Woodmar Lane lies just outside the doors to the north.

261.name: The Cathedral of Corruption
desc: "   The blackened walls of the Cathedral twist and turn their way
hundreds of feet into the air; rising in rebellion agains the feeble
power of virtue.  A gaping hole in the ground reaks of the bowels of
hell.  From the center of the pit, you feel the chilling power of evil
begin to take hold...devouring...consuming...filling your soul to the
very core.  Here, at the heart of Evil, you're stronger than one-
thousand men.  The room to the south bears the Altar of Rebellion in
inky darkness.  Pools of darkness to the left and right indicate
extensions of the Cathedral.

262.name: The Altar of Rebellion
desc: "   The Altar of Rebellion stands before you, engulfed in a shadow darker
than the depths of Hell.  An irrational fear races through you...the
power is too great...the cost too high...  Resolutely, you regain hold
of your senses in time to prevent your sanity from slipping into the
darkness.  Here, pilgrims from across the land come to sacrifice in the
name of Evil.  A twisted passage to the north leads back to the Cathedral.

263.name: An Aclove West of the Cathedral of Corruption
desc: "   The wailing of ten thousand tortured souls echos through the chambers
of the Cathedral.  The blood of the innocent trickles from the walls as
the smell of burning flesh assails your nostrils.  A passage cloaked in
darkness leads back to the Cathedral.

264.name: An Aclove East of the Cathedral of Corruption
desc: "  The heat of the forges of Hell rises from a hole in the floor.  Looking
down the maw of the hole, you see an eerie red glow far below.  You
quickly step back as the manical laughter of daemons fills your ears.
A portal in the west wall leads back to the darkness of the Cathedral.

265.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "  The Inverness river flows from the sleuce gates in the east wall of
the city of Midgard.  You might be able to make inside the sleuce gates
if you paddle real hard and fight the horrendous current.  The river
continues to the west at modest rate.

266.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The river here turns from the east to the south.  To the west, you
have a great view of The Amber Rose Restraunt, finest dining spot in
Midgard.  The mirrors crystal in the windows reflects the blue water
of the Inverness.

267.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The current flows briskly from the north and out toward the west.
Just downstream, you see that Main Street crosses the Inverness in
two places.  Between the two bridges is what appears to be a boat
shop.

268.name: Under a Bridge on Main Street
desc: "   You're passing under the first bridge to cross the Inverness River.
Looking up, you can see that a bright green moss has found a happy home
under the wooden planks.  The current here flows briskly from east to
west.

269.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "  The pace of the Inverness quickens slightly as it curves from the east
to the south.  On the north bank, you see a large building that could only
be the town hall.  Bridges on Main Street cross the river both upstream
and downstream of this location.

270.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   On the west shore, the Midgard Defense Headquarters keeps a clear
eye out for danger.  A bridge arches over the blue waters of the
Inverness just downstream.  The current here flows from the north to the
south.

271.name: Under a Bridge on Main Street
desc: "   The second bridge to cross the Inverness lies just overhead.  Even
though they're continually pelted by water, the boards of the bridge
show little sign of wear or decay...they must have been treated with
a special material.  The current flows from the north to the south.

272.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   A wooden bridge crosses the river just upstream.  A few rocks makes
the way a bit more dangerous as the river curves from the north to
the west.  There seems to be a fork in the river a bit downstream.

273.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The river here comes very close to the juncture of Circle Way and
Main Street.  Looking carefully, you can see people stop to wave to
you before continuing on their way.  The river curves from the east
to the south.

274.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "  The river picks up pace as it pounds its way southeast.  The current
runs briskly from north to south, and, a bit downstream, the river
forks off to the east and west.

275.name: A Fork in the Inverness River
desc: "  Just south of here, the Inverness river seems to have run into a very
stubborn rock.  Rather than trying to move it, the river flows to both
sides.  The main portion of the river continues to the west, and a
small tributary branches off to the east.

276.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The current slows down a bit now that you're off the main river.  The
current here travels from the west and then makes a turn to the south.  Far
downstream, you see the Catheral of Corruption looming on the horizon.

277.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The river churns slowly from the north to the south.  There isn't much
to see at this part of Midgard.  The industrial zone lies out of sight
to the south.

278.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   Iron Road crosses the river just down stream on its way to the
industrial section of Midgard.  To the southeast, a plume of smoke
rises from one of a cluster of shops.  As you travel down this tributar,
they river is becoming more and more shallow.

279.name: Under the Bridge on Iron Road
desc: "   The steel bridge above block out almost all light.  Luckily, it's
narrow enough so that you don't lose all sense of vision.  A bit further
south, you see that the river becomes little more than a trickle of
water between the stones.

280.name: The End of the Inverness River
desc: "   It's become almost impossible to travel here by raft.  The current
has slowed down and the bottom of the boat often scraps the riverbed.
To the east, you see a huge wharf spanning the breadth of the Inverness.
The current flows, as always, from north to south.

281.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   To the east, the two tributaries of the Inverness River combine
to form a larger river.  Glancing to the south, you see a few people
on Iron Road waving hysterically.  Having gotten your attention, they
smile broadly and go on about their business.

282.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   The current here flows from the north down to the west.  The Shrine
of Neutrality sits on the horizon to the northwest, while large wharf
spans the Inverness River to the southwest.   A bit of water sloshes
into the boat, getting your feet wet.

283.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   Just upstream, a smaller tributary of the Inverness joins this branch
to form a thicker, more powerful river.  The current flows from the
east to the south, where it disappears under a huge wharf.

284.name: Under the Wharf
desc: "   The northeast corner of the wharf blocks out almost all the sunlight
from above.  The river churns among the huge posts which support the
wharf.  You can go either upstream to the north or downstream to the
south.

285.name: Under the Wharf
desc: "   This far under the wharf, it's become completely black.  The creaking
of boards overhead indicate travelers crossing the wharf.  You briefly
wonder if they know that you're under here.  You can travel either up-
river to the north or downriver to the west.

286.name: Under the Center of the Wharf
desc: "   The river has taken you directly under the wharf which serves as
a crossroads between Woodmar Lane and the Iron Road.  Directly overhead,
a maintence hatch opens to the center of the wharf.  The river flows
from east to west.

287.name: Under the Wharf
desc: "   The river has taken you to the far west side of the wharf.  The
boards overhead completely blocks out all light.  The river takes
another turn from the east down to the south.

288.name: Under the Wharf
desc: "   Under the southwest corner of the wharf, a bit of daylight manages
to peek through to light your way.  In this dim light the waters of
the Inverness look almost black.  You can go either north or west.

289.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "  Glancing around, you notice the camp of the Shadow Guard off to the west.
Watchful eyes keep a careful eye on you from atop barbed wire fences.  A
bit farther to the south, you see a large iron grate blocking the way under
the city wall.

290.name: On the Inverness River
desc: "   Directly to the east, the Cathedral of Corruption raises its walls
in defiance.  Even from this distance, you can sense the strong evil
coming from the walls.  The current tends to carry your boat from the
north to the south.

291.name: Under the City Wall, On the Inverness River
desc: "   The Inverness has carried you all the way to the southern city wall.
To protect agains invaders, a sturdy iron grate has been put up to
block both entry and exit.  The only other way out is back upstream

292.name: Drifting down the River
desc: "   You aimlessly drift with the mild current downstream past the city
wall of Midgard.  As you leave civilization behind, you feel peaceful.
The river takes you slowly sout as you notice the river is becoming
more shallow and beginning to dry up.

293.name: The End of the Inverness River
desc: "   That's it...end of the line...The river has dried up so much that
it's become impossible to travel further to the south.  If you
struggled, you might be able to row your boat out of the muck further
upstream.  Better try, cause it's the only way you'll get out of here.

294.name: The Edge of Midnight Thicket
desc: "     You stand on the brink of the Midnight Thicket.  Rumored to be one of
the most dangerous forests in the known world, many parties have entered
never to be seen again.  You can still see the West Gate and long to be there
instead of on the brink of this dread woodlands.

295.name: The Entrance to Midnight Thicket
desc: "    Even during the brightest day little light get's down here.  Only the fact
that you are so close to the entrance makes it possible to see at all.  All
those tales you heard in you childhood start coming back with startling
clarity.

296.name: Floating Through the Ether
desc: "   This room gives you the exact same feeling as the null-space between
Quick-Go Boothes...  The air here is charged with electricity as a
powerful magic barrier keeps the chaos of the Ether from entering this
abode.  In one corner of the room, a small three dimensional model of
Midgard sits on a large, ebony table.  Mystical portals lead off in
several different directions.

297.name: Midnight Thicket
desc: "    Stories of young boys straying from the path only to return as zombies or
worse to attack passing travelers make you very sure that this is not a path
to stray from, even if you are the grown men and women defending your city
from all sorts of evil monsters.

298.name: Midnight Thicket
desc: "    The dark completely enshrouds you now.  At high noon the sun is but a
faint memory.  There is nothing to do but stay on the path and hope for the
best as you hurry to reach your journey's end.

301.name: A muddy river bed
desc: "  You are standing up to your knees in the muddy river bed.  The travelling
is quite ardurous here.  The river actually starts flowing again to the
north while the bed is totally dry to the south.  There are mosquitos
everywhere as the climate is quite humid.

302.name: Police Headquarters
desc: "   You are standing in the foyer of a large marble floored room.
The room is filled with people milling all around, some waiting
in line to be seen at the large desk that runs all along one side
of the room, the farthest from the door, others obviously injured
and giving information to a police officer.  Every now and then
a citizen sees someone being brought in my the police and a shouting
match erupts.  Looking around the police headquarters is a fine
building and there are two large leading deeper in the building.
A person lunges past you and screams at someone behind you, "you thief.. "
and is quickly pulled away by the guards before they come to blows.

303.name: Police Headquarters
desc: "   You are standing in the foyer of a large marble floored room.
The room is filled with people milling all around, some waiting
in line to be seen at the large desk that runs all along one side
of the room, the farthest from the door, others obviously injured
and giving information to a police officer.  Every now and then
a citizen sees someone being brought in my the police and a shouting
match erupts.  Looking around the police headquarters is a fine
building and there are two large leading deeper in the building.
You are pushed aside as two burly officers drag in a large
warrior.  The warrior, still fighting the officers, snarls at you.

304.name: High Court of Midgard
desc: "   You are in the High Court of Midgard.  It is a simple room, reminiscent
of times when Midgard was much smaller than it is now.  Above the judge's
bench  there is a large crest.  The furniture in the court consists of a
large oak bench, which the judge sits behind, two small desks before that,
and far behind those, several long benches for the public.  In one corner
you can see a small barred box, in which to contain dangerous prisoners.
Along the other wall, there are several chairs, for the jurors, in the
few cases that they are needed for.  There is an atmosphere of solemnity
about this room, a sense of justice, of great things that have happened
and have yet to happen.  At the moment the room is reasonably empty, the
silence is paramount.
"   The crest consists of a scales and sword.  Circling the mosaic
there is written, Justice to All, All are equal in the Law.

305.name: Guardroom
desc: "   You are at entrance to the guardroom.  It is really just a large room
with some offices leading off it.  Off to the back you can see part of the
jail itself.  There is the usual strained atmosphere of a police station,
fear and desperation.  All around the room you can see the usual cheerful
messages, such as Don't Drink and Ride, help your neighbour, and warnings
about not leaving your house door unlock with adventurers in town.  The
station is so busy that the guards do not have any time to pay attention
to anyone who doesn't move deeper into the room.

307.name: Jail
desc: "   The guard on duty notices your entrance and immediately calls for help.
Quickly two burly officers push you into a cell.  The officer shouts in your
ear, "If you want to see our jails, stranger, have a closer look".
Looking at your cell from the inside you can see that is has all the
rudimentary requirements, a hole in the floor for sanitary purposes, and a
leaking, dripping, pipe for water.  Your only bed is a pile of straw in a
corner.  I suppose all you can do is wait.
"   It is a small hole, about three inches wide, to small for even a pixie
to escape through.  The dripping water falls down the hole, resulting in
a deep hollow plop when it lands at the bottom.  Fortunately the cities
famous sewerage system extends even to its jails, and so at least it doesn't
smell badly.
"   The jailer grabs you by the arm and pulls you out roughly.  He warns
you to mind your own business in future, and pushes you out onto the street.

307.flags: no_mob, indoors, peaceful, nosteal, no_magic, summon_trap, dispel_magic

311.name: A Small Alley
desc: "   You are in a small alley.  There are lots of soldiers
and fighting men lining the street, some with bruises
others with freshly minted weapons.  To the east you
can see a large building with powerful guards on
the entrance.

312.name: A Hallway Intersection
desc: "  Here two hallways meet forming a wide intersection.  An oil-lamp has been
attached to the ceiling, providing a welcoming light to the visitors and
present keepers.  Upon the floor lies a thick red carpet, stained with
dirt, filled with holes made from sharp high heels and armoured boots. The
walls have been decorated with historical paintings, soldiers upon great
war stallions, charging into battle, or fending off huge amounts of enemies.
The hallways continue towards the east and west, but also trail off
towards a more open area to the north.  A door leads to the street.
The lamp has been attached to the ceiling with a small silvery chain. The
lamp flickers as the wind finds its way through the cracks in the old stone
walls. The light feels welcoming and friendly.
"  Armoured men, soldiers riding their stallions into battle, charging with
the lances down, towards to opposing side.  Smoke arising from a distance,
men falling of horses with deadly wounds.

313.name: A Dull Corridor
desc: "  The hallway continues further east and west; here a wooden bench has been
placed along the northern wall, allowing the tired to have a seat and rest
heavy legs and worn feet.  On each side of the bench, a torch has been
attached, emitting its pale yellow light when lit during night time.
A wooden board lies upon the floor here, covering a hazardous hole in the
stone floor, allowing servants to rush back and forth without risking a
dangerous fall. To the east, a pine door block further passage. The hallway
continuos to the west, where the exit is located.
"  Made from pine tree, this bench have been created from one single piece
of log, carved into a comfortable looking bench.
"  An square, cut out from beech wood, this protects the passing from the
hazardous hole below.  Bolts have been driven deep into the stone from at
each corner of the board, making it stay in correct position.

314.name: Inside a Library
desc: "  You find yourself inside a small room, filled to the maximum capacity
with bookshelves. Along the northern, eastern and southern walls, three
massive shelves have been placed, filled with hundreds of books and
journals.  Light comes from an oil lamp standing upon a small round table
in the northern corner of the room.  Another table stands in the center of
the room, allowing its visitor to sit down, while looking into a journal or
book.  A sign has been nailed above the door reading "Journal and Books may
not leave this record hall without permission".  The exit lies to the west,
with a pine door providing protection from noise and unwanted guests.
"  Tons of books, journals and tomes fill these shelves. A thick layer of
dust covers the books and shelves.  Each level in the bookshelf has an big
letter, indicating where books are placed.

extra.desc: "  Small and simply crafted, this oil lamp provides light to the room.

315.name: Before the Training Yard
desc: "  You find yourself in a dressing room, used by the warriors before or
after combat training.  Two wooden benches line the eastern and western
wall, allowing current visitors to sit down, while strapping off or on
armour.  The thick red carpet is barely visible beneath the dirt covering
its surface here, holes apparent where armoured boots have torn through the
rug at several places.  A wooden sign has been nailed to the eastern wall
here, announcing that sharpened weapons are used at the training
yard, which might lead to injury or even death.  A pile of broken armour lies
lies by the southeastern corner, mostly hardened leather that took one too
many blows.  The arch in the northern wall allows access to the training
yard, while a hallway is located south from here.
"  Plain and simple, these benches were made in order to hold several well
armoured fighters at once, while strapping on and off armour.
"  Armour made from tanned or blackened leather lie piled up here.  Cracks
and deep bruises have been made upon them, when too many blows have been
aimed at the same spot, or when someone powerful got in an dangerous blow.

316.name: A Dull Corridor
desc: "  The floor here consists only of cold stone, cleaned with care daily.
Torches are attached to the wall, flickering as the wind finds its way through
cracks in the dull grey structure.  Several heraldic shields are nailed to
the walls here, religious symbols painted upon their polished surfaces.
Above each shield, upon small iron hooks, hang two crossed rapiers,
glimmering in the dim light provided by the torches.  The sounds of
servants moving upon the cold stone floor echoes through the house, as time
keeps on running.  The hallway continues further east and west from here.
"  The torches stand in small iron baskets, that have been nailed into the
cold stone walls.  They flicker some, as the wind finds its way through
cracks in the walls.
"  Slender and light-weighted, these rapiers have been attached securely to
the wall, thick iron hooks hold them up, as well as guard them.  There
sharp edges glimmers in the dim light provided by the torches.

317.name: Sharp Turn in the Corridor
desc: "  The hallway takes a sharp turn here, trailing off further north and east.
A thick black carpet covers the floor here, made by a skilled hand, and
kept clean by the servants daily.  Further north the hallway opens up into
a medium-sized meeting hall.  A painting upon the wall shows a giant stone
fortress, standing firm within a forest clearing, flags waving high above
in the air.  Here and there the walls have been repaired, old grey stone
replaced with shinning white stone.  The hallway runs further east and
north from here, with the meeting hall to the north.
"  This carpet sure is a piece of hand-work.  Woven by a trained hand, it
nearly covers the whole corridor.  The colour seem to shift as light
strikes it surface, to decide whether its deep blue or deep black is an
time consuming task.
"  An huge stone fortress that could have been build hundreds of years ago.
This fort could probably keep an army outside for weeks.

318.name: The Training Yard
desc: "  The air lies virtually still here.  The medium-sized backyard lies in
protection from the houses surrounding it, allowing less wind to find its
way in.  Heavy packed dirt serves as an excellent floor, as heavy armoured
soldiers work their skills when training.  At the eastern and
western corner of the yard, training dummies have been attached on thick
oak poles, allowing the warriors to practice their deadly moves.  Further
north lies three small wooden storage buildings, their inside blocked of by
reinforced wooden doors.  Some score tables have been inscribed into the
stone walls here, several of them slowly fading away as time passes.  The
house itself lies to the south, one must pass through the arch in order to
access the inner rooms.
"  Two rotating arms upon an thick oak log, serves as well functional
training dummies.  A shield has been placed it its left hand, and a sturdy
wooden club in the right hand, allowing both blocking and offensive
training.
"  Max the Deadly - Gertrud von Rutherbaum : 3-5
Gramer Ironfist - Tygen Steelhand : 3-3
Kira Hawkeye - Taliron Elfbane : 5-1
The rest seem to faded to read out.

319.name: The Training Yard
desc: "  The air lies virtually still here.  The medium-sized backyard lies in
protection from the houses surrounding it, allowing less wind to find its
way in.  Heavy packed dirt serves as an excellent floor, as heavy armoured
boots and soldiers work their skills when training.  At the northern wall,
training dummies have been attached to oak poles, making them able to
rotate, blocking and striking.  The ground has been stained with blood here
and there, reminding the warriors that even training here might lead to
fatal injury, and in worse cases, death.  The yard reaches out further west
from here, where the entrance to the guild is located.
"  Two rotating arms upon an thick oak log, serves as well functional
training dummies.  A shield has been placed it its left hand, and a sturdy
wooden club in the right hand, allowing both blocking and offensive
training.
"  Long dried blood stain the dirt ground here, reminding people that
training might be dangerous when technique fails.

320.name: The Training Yard
desc: "  The air lies virtually still here.  The medium-sized backyard lies in
protection from the houses surrounding it, allowing less wind to find its
way in.  Heavy packed dirt serves as an excellent floor, as heavy armoured
boots and soldiers work their skills when training.  At the northern wall,
training dummies have been attached to oak poles, making them able to
rotate, blocking and striking.  The ground has been stained with blood here
and there, reminding the warriors that even training here might lead to
fatal injury, and in worse cases, death.  The yard reaches out further east
from here, where the entrance to the guild is located.
"  Two rotating arms upon an thick oak log, serves as well functional
training dummies.  A shield has been placed it its left hand, and a sturdy
wooden club in the right hand, allowing both blocking and offensive
training.
"  Long dried blood stain the dirt ground here, reminding people that
training might be dangerous when technique fails.

321.name: Inside a Wooden Shrank
desc: "  The small wooden storage room smells damp, light filtering in only from
the entrance of the shrank.  A rug covers the dust-filled floor, rats moving
across the floor in search of shadow to hide in.  Upon low shelves lies
worn leather armour, which is intended to serve as protective gear when
sparring against another person.  The walls lean slightly inwards, making
the shrank smaller then it was constructed to be, and the ceiling looks like it
could crash down at any minute.  Fresh air flows in from the south, where the
training yard is located.
"  Brown in colour, this rug has been placed here to cover the dust filled
floor.

322.name: Inside a Wooden Hut
desc: "  The small wooden storage room smells damp, light is allowed in only from
the entrance of the hut.  The ground consists of heavily pressed dirt, rats
rush across the floor in search of a save-hiding place among the shadows.
Several wooden weapons are scattered around the room; clubs and pikes,
swords and staffs, used as training weapons by visitors.  A pile of broken
weapons lies at the southern corner of the shrank, left there to be
repaired.  Fresh air flows in from the south, where the training yard is
located.
"  Pikes, swords and clubs, all these weapons have been repaired several
times.  The condition of the weapons vary a lot, some of them will never be
used again, while others just need a quick look-over and some repairs.

323.name: Inside a Storage Room
desc: " The small wooden storage room smells damp, light filtering in only from
the entrance of the room. The small storage room is filled to its limit
with wooden benches, tables and chairs stacked on top of each other. The
ceiling has been repaired during the years, planks have been replaced, in
order to keep the weather out, although the wind still has no trouble of
finding entrance through the thin wooden walls. The walls seem filled with
moisture, rotten to the very center. The training yard is located to the
south, outside in the fresh air.
"  Brown in colour, this rug has been placed here to cover the dust filled
floor.

324.name: A Dry River Bed
desc: "  The river bed has totally dried up here because of the intense dryness
in the climate.  The perspiration is pouring off your brow like a
waterfall in this heat.  You are becoming fatigued as you walk along the
bed.  The bed to the north looks quite muddy while to the south it is
perfectly dry.

325.name: A Grand Entryway
desc: "   Two large crystal chandeliers hang from the ceiling near entry, each
demanding attention.  Each contains numerous tapered candles, the flames
reflecting a thousand times over in the carven crystal that comprises the
chandelier.  When combined with the light of single candles in sconces of
stone around the room, the room is bathed in soft, sparkling light.
The floor is parquet and has been cunningly constructed with a light
pine background, as well as darker oak and cherry criss-crossing that
interlock in squares.
Along the western wall, the light splashes across windows that span
to the ceiling above. A myriad of oil-painted portraits, some framed in
gold and others in silver, hang along the walls between the sconces.
Large bolts of silk, each dyed in rich colors, have been draped across
the top of the portraits, falling down around the sides. A plushly
carpeted hallway stretches out to the north, and a large door lies
to the south.

326.name: A Large Kitchen
desc: "   Considerable in size, this kitchen's walls and floor have been made from
a glazed, blue-painted brick. A sturdy and large, cast-iron oven stands in
room's center. A few shelves have been constructed to protrude from the
oven's sides, allowing one to set pots or necessities alongside for easy
reach. Cabinets standing about one foot tall stretch along the west wall,
holding foods for cooking. The smell of salted meat and smoke is thick in
this room, although not overbearing. A doorway stands to the east, leading
out into a hallway.

327.name: A Lavish Bedchamber
desc: "   The centerpiece of this room, a wide and almost gaudy looking bed
stands in the middle. The frame has been constructed from a solid,
grey-painted iron, lying low to the ground. Raising a few feet high,
the headboard's sides shoot up straight before forming a smooth,
curling, intricate pattern of flowers and leaves toward the center. A
polished ivory figurine of a dove has been positioned in the middle of
the headboard, wings outstretched, with a vine in its beak. Four long
posters adorn the sides of the bed, and sheer white silk has been draped
along the top, swirling around airily and hanging down with thick bolts.
Stained dark and polished, a cedar dresser stands against the southern
wall. A circular crystal vase stands on the dresser's top in the leftmost
corner, a single creamy-white rose peeking out. A small, brass-plated mirror
hangs above the dresser, casting a soft, reflective light around the room
when sunlight filters in and hits it.
A small nightstand rests to one side of the bed, lacking drawers, but
providing suitable space to hold smaller knick-knacks. A tiny glass oil
lamp, stenciled with emerald-dyed leaves and pink flowers, has been placed
on the nightstand, a strip of lace surrounding its base.
A well-sized bathing chamber can be seen to the north, and a door stands
to the east, leading back to the hallway.

328.name: A Short Carpeted Hallway
desc: "   This wide, plush-grey carpeted hallway is lined by black-iron
sconces, about a third of them lit. The flickering shadows from
the sconces stretch across the rough three-foot width of the hall.
From waist height and up, the walls of the hallway are covered by
panels of a deep colored oak wood.
Toward the floors, the walls are made of a rough, dark stone,
looking as if it was bricked into place. The ceiling raises up about
seven feet high, with solid and richly-polished beams interlaced for
support. To the west, an open doorway leads into the kitchen, the
smell of buttered bread and cooked meats seeping out from it. A
large, stately-looking door with a brass knob stands to the east,
and the hallway extends southward.

329.name: A Tile Bathing Chamber
desc: "   Black tiles, cut fastiduously into various shapes, have been
laid with precision and form artistic patterns that stretch across the
floor. A crimson-dyed wardrobe lies nestled within a small alcoved corner,
one door hanging crookedly. Upon closer inspection, it is obvious that one
of the brass hinges are missing. A rounded, black-stone bathing tub stands
against the west wall beneath a tiny window. Two thin, black-iron racks hang
next to the tub. Thick, fluffy towels lie folded neatly on the shelves of
one rack, and the other rack holds a colorful array of small perfumed vials,
as well as musky, masculine-smelling chunks of soap. A small, black-marble
statue, fashioned into the form of a flying dove, stands on the east wall.
The beak is opened slightly, and a thin but steady strem of incense smoke
circles up into the air the beak.
A thin archway stands within the southern wall, leading into the bedroom.

330.name: Talamark's Armour Shop
desc: "   Thick lacquered wooden frames and smooth oaken racks display
the finished products of the forge.  Metal armours of all types,
from heavy plate mail to delicately woven chain are on display,
gleaming brightly with a fresh polish.  Many of the armours have
minute detail work and engravings, filigrees and other trim, all
beatiful to behold and functional in its protection.  Hanging off
of iron wrought hooks are the hardened leather armours, fine work
tooled along its surface, supple yet strong.  Alongside one wall
are locked display cases filled with fur trimmed gloves and heavy
metal jointed gauntlets, helmets with polished horns and even
intricately designed helms.

331.name: Talamark's Armoury
desc: "   Clouds of pure white steam cling to every corner, as the blazing
heat from the forges fill the room.  A loud cacophany of metal ringing
upon metal fills the room, as the acrid stench of charred metal wafts
in on the smoke from the forges.  In the center of the armoury is a
ring of three forges, built of stone and sand, each of the forges in
the process of smelting a different type of metal.  To the side of the
ring of forges is a small crystal pool of water.  Base sand molds for
the component parts of armor lie stacked neatly against the wall, as
heavy hammers, tongs, and other assorted tools lie scattered across
the ground.
The ring of forges is solidly built of heavy basalt stone.  Clean
white sand lies at the bottom of the forge to help in the removal
of excess carbons from metal, and small slanted holes set at the
bottom of each forge allow the pouring off of slag, so that pure
metals can be used in the armours.
A rectangular pool of clear water is set to the side of the ring
of forges, for quick quenching of metals.

332.name: The Working Room
desc: "   Long oaken tables lean against the wall of the room.  A vast
assortment of tools lie scattered along its surface: heavy iron
hammers, long thin pliers, long wrought tongs, and other tools
spans the entire length of the table.  Sand molds with finished
strips of metal for splinted and banded mail, heavy rings for
the chain mail mantles and hauberks, and thick heavy plates of
the hardest metals for the heavier, more protective armours,
are all gathered on the table.  Burnishing and etching tools of
the finest quality are at one corner of the tables, their fine
tips used for the delicate engraving for the finished armor. A
pile of rags lie in a bucket under the tables, their surface is
covered in a light fine oil to aid in the prevention of rust for
the finished products.
On the table are sand molds of various types, each of them
taking a casting of a specific part of armor.

333.name: The Barbarians' Practice Field
desc: "   A field of waving grass stretches out in all directions as far as the
eye can see.  It's an illusion, of course, but it still brings back
memories of the barbarian way of life before this...city.  The only
thing in the field besides yourself is your guildmaster.

334.name: The Tannery
desc: "   Open slats set into the roof allow the heat to escape the
tannery, allowing the leather armours within to dry and cure
properly.  Wooden mannequins of different sizes stand nearby,
shaping the different styles of light leather armours.  Off
to the farthest corner of the room is a well ventilated area,
which contain vats of different colored dyes used to stain
the armours.  Whole sheets, and long strips of tooled leather,
hang from the wall, drying and hardening.  A long roughly
hewn table rests against the wall, hammers and awls, and
other leather working tools lie scattered across its wooden
surface.  An oaken barrel of water lies in the center of
the room, to ease in the shaping of the armours.
Smooth wooden mannequins of different shapes and sizes are
used to help in the finishing of the production of leather
armours.
A multitude of vats containing many different colors of dyes,
are used in the coloring and staining of armours.

335.name: The Storage Room
desc: "   Glimmering piles of ingots are stacked in neat and orderly rows
against the wall, their myriad of dark colors reflecting dimly from
the light of the forge.  A line of smooth wooden mannequins of all
different shapes and sizes are placed across from the ingots.  Row
upon row of sand molds for different parts of armor lie near the
finished ingots, while heavy iron buckets of unfinished ore are
placed near the ceramic jars of mud and stacked bales of hay.  An
assortment of extra tools and hammers are hung from hooks placed
within the walls, their bright surface gleaming faintly in the
flames reflecting from the forge.
Various ingots of smelted metals are stacked neatly against the
wall.  Their metals range from the dark dull color of iron to
the bright gleaming surface of mithril to the light absorbing
abscence of colors of the adamantite.
There are many heavy iron buckets near the bales of hay used for
the forging process.  Within these buckets are different types of
ore that need to be smelted and purified for creation of armors.

336.name: An Alcove
desc: "   Beyond the reach of the thick choking smoke and blazing heat is
a small alcove set in the recess of the storage room.  Within is a
simple sturdy wooden desk and chair, plain and unadorned,  resting
against the wall.  On top of the table are a few books and a small
marble statue.  Across from the desk is a long thin bed, furnished
with nothing more than a small rough pillow and wormeaten blanket.
A small brass lantern, worked into the shape of a coiling dragon,
sheds its illumination onto the unadorned furnishings.
On top of the desk are a handful of books of varying subjects on
metallurgy and alloys for the creation of armours.
A small statue of grey marble carved lovingly into the shape of
a bear.  He has an eternal smirk on his face and set within his
paws is a thin cylindrical device that betokens destruction and
doom...

337.name: The Crimson Clover Inn - Kitchen
desc: "   This kitchen has obviously been designed for maximum production and
efficiency.  Fires are set within steel lattices, from which hang large
cauldrons of boiling stew.  Activity never ceases, as the cooks run madly
from counter to counter, cutting meat and vegetables, skewering, baking
bread in the stone hearths and shouting orders and questions back and forth.
The clatter of dishes and pots mingles with the sound of raised voices and
creates a strangely pleasant cacophany -- this room is filled with the sound
of honest, hard work, and the cleanliness and savoury odoours suggest that a
certain amount of pride is taken in it.

338.name: The Crimson Clover Inn
desc: "   This room is vast, the ceilings stretching up beyond the ability of the
lanterns to illuminate them and the walls running so extensively in either
direction that it is difficult to discern objects or persons from one extreme
of the room to the other.  Bookshelves line the walls, full of preciously
bound volumes in a wide assortment of colours.  Numerous hearths and firepits
are scattered about the room, with tables and chairs arranged alongside of
them.  Serving women scurry back and forth constantly, taking and delivering
orders from the numerous patrons.  A scent of fresh herbs and meat permeates
the air, and the sound of multiple conversations blend into a single murmur
that washes across the room in waves.  Despite its massive size, this room
at no point seems vacant or cavernous, and appears to have been expressly
designed to appeal to its patrons sense of "home".
"   As you run your fingers along the spines of these books, one in particular
catches your attention.  Bound in pale blue, its title is simply:
"The Crimson Clover".
"   This book describes the history of the Inn in great detail, beginning
thusly:
It came about that a young man was born in the village of Zyre, and that
upon reaching his maturity did seek the world itself, and so began a life in
adventuring.  The name given him by his parents was "Jsil", a simple name
that translates roughly to correspond to the feeling one might have lying on
their back in a field of wild flowers.  He left the village because he felt
in himself a compulsion to do so, but went with a heavy heart and numerous
misgivings.
For many years, he travelled, learning the ways of magic and warcraft, and
growing in reknown.  One of his adventures took him to the Terhim Barrows,
and he emerged from them a changed man, mistaken for mad by his companions. He
claimed to have been granted a prophecy while deep in the barrows, and to have
seen his beloved village razed to the ground.  To appease him, his companions
elected to come with him to the village, sure that he would return to his
merry self upon seeing that nothing untoward had occurred in his absence.
This was not the case.  The village, unvisited by Jsil for many years, had
been utterly destroyed.  Not a trace of its inhabitants remained, save for
the burnt husks of houses and the occasional bone, bleached by the sun and
likely belonging to a loved one of Jsil's. His grief overcame him, and he
stumbled into the holy grove in the center of the village, though the trees
were now warped and twisted.  As he gazed down, however, he saw something
astonishing: the floor of the grove was carpeted in brilliantly crimson
clovers.
Once more, Jsil emerged from a place of death changed.  His madness and
grief had left him, or else had transmuted into a horrible resolve.  He
dedicated his life -- and it proved to be an exceptionally long one -- to
the annihilation of those who had seen fit to destroy his home.  He sought
out all who might have information, and gathered it, compelling it by force
and by magics, until he at last uncovered the identity of the nobles who had
given the order, who had slaughtered his people in the hopes that they would
reveal the secrets of the grove, secrets which existed only in folktales.
Those nobles dwelt where you now stand.  This inn was once their house,
symbol of their lineage.  Jsil, now dubbed "Khalis'az'In" -- bloodletter --
marched from room to room, massacreing every inhabitant, from the youngest
child to the most revered elder.  Upon finishing his work, he impaled himself
within the room that now bears the mosaic of the clover.
This mosaic did not appear unnaturally, however.  It was created by master
craftsmen hired by Skriven, the founder of the inn.  The property, widely
believed to be cursed, was essentially granted to Skriven by the city due to
his valour in a relatively minor battle.  After researching the source of the
alleged "curse", Skriven elected to celebrate rather than conceal the heritage
behind the structure.
It is for these reasons that this Inn is known as "The Crimson Clover".

339.name: The Crimson Clover Inn - Reception
desc: "   This delightfully decorated room is draped in lengths of red cloth and
lit by lanterns encased within crystal.  A winding staircase ascends to the
upper floors, upon which private rooms can be discoered.  A large desk is
placed against the northern wall, where prospective patrons can either rent
a room or read the guestbook kept by the Inn.  A merry fire blazes in a large
fireplace against the western wall, the flickering orange light complementing
the purer tones given off by the crystalline lamps.
Marvelous! I loved my stay!    -- Trinia De'Zen
If Svetlana should ever stay here, tell her I said hello.        -- Avestan
And tell her I miss her, too.          -- Avestan
This place smells like city people. I don't like it.         -- Trink
It's a bit morbid here, isn't it?  I mean, it's the site of a brutal massacre.
Does nobody else find that disturbing?             -- Talslin
That mosaic is beautiful!    -- Ferin

340.name: The Crimson Clover Inn - Common Room
desc: "  This room is large, and filled with row upon row of beds large enough to
accomodate even the largest of patrons.  Four fireplaces are set in each of
the south, west and eastern walls, blazing throughout the night in order to
warm those who would sleep here.  Unlike the common rooms of most inns, this
one provides for enough space that a guest need not feel uncomfortable due to
his proximity to others.  There also appears to be a marked lack of insects
and rodents, perhaps due to the washing basins distributed amongst the beds.
A few tables and chairs are provided as well, a thoughtful act directed towards
the insomniacs that might be present, as they permit one to read comfortably
by lamplight without keeping another awake.

341.name: The Crimson Clover Inn - Foyer
desc: "   The foyer to this inn is appointed in a deceptively rich manner.  While
the walls have the stain common to any number of country inns, their surface
is completely unmarred.  The floor is also impeccably clean, and laid in the
form of a mosaic depicting a red clover on a pale blue background.  Murals
run across the walls in a seemingly chaotic manner -- appearing, disappearing
and then reappearing at a later section.  A wide doorway leads to the east,
from which a smell of horse and hay can be detected.  A second passage runs
west, from which wafts the smell of cooking meat and vegetables, as well as
a murmur of conversation.  A third and final exit is set in the southern wall,  leading outside of the inn.  Oil lamps run along the walls in an evenly spaced
fashion, though their light can do little to illuminate the vaulted ceilings
that recede into shadows high above.
"   The murals make use of only three colours: red, white and black.  None of
them are fully fleshed, but rather contain line drawings of various creatures
both mythical and natural.  The style is primitive, and could almost be
mistaken for the scrawlings of a semi-talented employee, did the work not
radiate such power and grace.

342.name: Before The Crimson Clover Inn
desc: "   A white and blue cobblestone pathway winds its way through a lushly
overgrown garden, through the branches of which fly numerous birds and
through the brush of which crawl small creatures intent only upon their
existance, though perhaps even they can note the care and artistry that has
been expended in creating this landscape.  White oak benches occasionally
appear within the gardens, and overhanging willow trees create shaded areas
within which bubble springs and run streams.  The entirety of the gardens
appear to have been designed so as to lead to the massive building to the
north, constructed entirely of some unidentifiable but pleasing wood, mingled
here and there with reinforcements of smooth brown stone.  The door to the
building is open, and people come and go freely.  Above the entrance is a
simplistic sign depicting a red clover on a pale blue background.  Opposite the building, to the south, is the western road of Midgard.

343.name: The Western Stables
desc: "   The western portion of this vast room smells rather distinctly of horses,
hay and dung.  All three are quite easily explicable -- the horses are stabled
to the south, and a pile of hay occupies the northwestern of the room, set
alongside of a simple wooden door leading north and just to the side of the
entrance to the Crimson Clover Inn in the western wall.  The room is
almost cavernous in nature, easily accomodating several horses moving abreast.
Illumination is provided not by standard oil lamps, but instead by several
glowing balls set into the walls, a precaution against fires.

344.name: The Stablemaster's Quarters
desc: "   This room is relatively small considering the position and importance
of the man who occupies it, and its furnishings could be described only
generously as spartan.  A narrow bed barely suited to accomodating a single
person is flushed tightly against the eastern wall, and a small desk adorned
only with a neat stack of ledgers is placed against the northern.  The
western wall displays the only nod to decoration in the form of a mounted
etching, dark lines forming the figures of horses galloping across a glorious
specimen of white oak.  Rather incongruously, a small piece of leather hangs
from the wall alongside this artwork, battered and faded by time and elements.
The only exit from this room lies to the south, in the form of a plain but
sturdy oaken door.
"   This desk is well-constructed of lightened mahogany, and its surface is
pristine.  A stack of black leather-bound ledgers is sitting upon the desk.
"   These ledgers are meticulously kept, and note the condition and
requirements for each horse kept in the stables.  The handwriting is small
and fine, but easily legible.

345.name: The Stalls
desc: "   Each of the stalls in this room is more than worthy of accomodating even
the largest of chargers and warhorses.  The stalls have been built by a master
carpenter using ironwood, providing just enough give to prohibit the horses
from harming themselves and yet being strong enough to avoid being battered
down should a foul-tempered beast be lodged.  Fresh hay is always piled in the
stalls, and the water in the troughs is clear, clean and fit for even human
consumption.  A low and soothing light is provided by small globules
embedded high in the walls.  The smell of dung and horses hangs heavy in the
air, mingling with the sweetness of the hay.

346.name: The Eastern Stables
desc: "   The eastern portion of this cavernous room is extremely neat, with the
floors displaying evidence of having been recently swept.  The exit from the
stables lies eastwards, and is broad enough to accomodate a small cavalry
troupe.  The only objects of note within this room are several small stools
and sawhorses, used for re-shoeing any horses that require it.  Doors are
present in both the north and south walls, whilst the main stables continue
to the west.  Despite the massive size of this structure, it is pleasantly lit
by several glowing balls set into the building itself, casting light sufficient
for whatever work needs be done.

347.name: The Stablehand's Quarters
desc: "   This room accomodates the stablehands, and reflects their comfortable but
low station in life.  Three narrow beds are arranged in a row, with a simple
footlocker resting at the foot of each.  A few pieces of tack hang from the
walls along with some rough-spun clothing.  The room is exceptionally tidy
considering the average age of its occupants, with the only evidence of
youthful exuberance being an occasional piece of writing scrawled upon the
dark wood walls.  Lamps are mounted strategically to provide light, with one
small lamp alongside of each bed.
I'm outta this place and off to live a life of adventure!    --Tejan
Did you see the wench with Wirdin last night? How much did he drink? --Frin
At least I GOT a wench!   --Wirdin
You sure about that?  -- Ginny

348.name: The Tack Room
desc: "  This large room is devoted entirely to the grooming and maintenance of
horses.  The south, west, and eastern walls each have a workbench that is
literally covered in various tools, brushes and jarred salves and balms,
an assemblage so complex as to border on the arcane.  Several stools of varying
height are placed against the eastern wall, to be moved and used as required.
Despite the incredible amount of equipment to be found here, the room does not
seem remotely cluttered or out-of-order, but instead exemplifies efficient
and worthy use of space.

361.name: Council Chambers
desc: The council chambers are fairly plain.  A large, round table sits in the
center, surrounded by nine chairs.  Each of the chairs is marked with a name;
Toidi, Bingo, Krisanth, and so on, for each of the council members.  A vending
machine is to the south, filled with all sorts of yummies and goodies. At
resonable prices.  The mayors office lies to the west, where the mayor goes
to relax after the council meetings.  You see a large sign on the wall, and
a smaller one below it.
It emits a faint humming sound!
You can see all sorts of goodies...M&M's, snickers, butterfingers...

362.name: The hills
desc: "   You are on a path leading north, small hills surrounds you. You feel
the forces of evil approach you from the north.

378.name: City Entrance
desc: "   You stand on the outskirts of a large city - Midgard; the capital of this
land. The road leads east into the peace and quiet - and dangers - of the
forest; and to the west it becomes the main street of the town; surrounded by
a confusion of shops, bars, and market places.

391.name: The Fish Market
desc: "   The clamor of activity grows louder as you enter the
fish market. All around you, busy merchants and
longshoremen brush past you carrying heavy loads of fresh
fish.  Hawkers and buyers haggle animatedly over whole fish
and slabs of fish lying on scales and dripping from hooks.
The stalls of several fish merchants are sheltered from the
sun by dirty canvas awnings, underneath which on makeshift
shelves and beds of chipped ice sit huge piles of dead fish
of every color and size imaginable. The overwhelming smell
and scurry of people around this place force you to either
stop and buy some fish or hurry on.

392.name: The Fish Market
desc: "   As you make your way down the wharf, the pervasive smell
of gutted fish, dried fish, beheaded fish, people yelling
'Fish!' followed by declarations of their low, low prices,
you begin to get the craving for a steak.  On your right is
a shellfish stand with buckets of shrimp, crates of crabs
and bushels of mussels and clams for sale.  The bare-
chested proprietor stops yelling in general and begins
yelling at you, encouraging you that his are the finest
shrimp, caught just this morning from the bay.  Down the
wharf, the stalls begin to have large buckets the size of
baby pools, hundreds of fish churning the several inch deep
water, black and white with fish tails and foam. Large fish
hang from hooks, black glassy eyes reflecting the light
at you.

393.name: Under the Awning
desc: "   You pass underneath an unusually large awning reaching
out from the only genuine fish shop out here by the water.
The walls of the shop appear to be made of plywood, but
that's more than the crate and barrel borders most of the
stalls that bother have created.  Barrels of dried fish
line shelves of fresh herring, salmon, and perch up against
the entrance to the shop.  An aquarium of small turtles
gurgles away in a corner while several small children poke
at the soon to be soup dinners with sticks.  People wrap
their selections with newspaper and make their way into the
shop to pay. Although you don't see anyone, you feel the
watchful eye of the proprietor on you nevertheless.

394.name: The Fish Shop
desc: "   The inside of the shop is cramped and tight, the smell
of fish both long since sold and fresh caught lingers
heavily in the half-lit air. Not much of a draft makes it
through the slatted window in the back.  Rows of fish,
shellfish and some bizarre looking sea creatures sit on the
ice shelves, those with eyes you can discern staring
blankly. Large scales hang precariously from the ceiling.
Behind the main fish counter laden with catch is the
storekeeper, a big, soft, foul looking woman with a sour
look on her face, a bloody fishgut-splattered apron around
her neck, and a monster cleaver in her hand. She's
beheading several large bony fish on a butcher block
without even looking at what she's doing, because she's
watching you. "So do you want to buy something or are you
going to stand there all day?".

395.name: The Antechamber
desc: "   A pair of long benches, made of intricately carved and polished
mahogany, decorates the antechamber room.  Huge comfortable pillows
line the benches, their sunken depths inviting to the touch.  There
is a small table of worn cherry wood, which has a small statue made
of pure grey marble atop it.  A light coating of a dark coarse dust,
mixed with ash, covers the floor, as the acrid stale smell of smoke
and metal filters in from the room beyond.
"   A small statue of greying marble rests on the worn table.  The
statue appears to be of a small grey bear with a constant smirk
on his face, wielding a cylindrical device with a button set in
its length, bespeaking doom and destruction of ages past.

396.name: The Weapons Room
desc: "   Huge oaken racks containing swords and daggers of various
sizes, styles, and components rests against the wall.  A broad
length of iron hooks hold the many types of hammers and maces,
as polearms of varying blades and lengths are displayed in a
polished mahogany rack opposite the swords.  A long display case
lies to one side of the room, within its depths is the glittering
of highly polished and decorated weapons that were recently
forged.

397.name: Dalarks's Forge
desc: "   Intense, stagnant heat and voluminous smoke fill the air of the
forge.  A pit of bright orange molten metal lies in the center of
the room, with constant waves of heat eminating from it.  A large
barrel of crystal clear water rest near the anvil for quenching.
The old large anvil is composed of some form of bluish metal, worn
smooth from years of use.  A long table filled with all manner of
tools rests along the far side of the wall.  Hammers, tongs, and
other assorted tools lie scattered among the ingots and failed
projects produced by the forge.
"   A large oaken barrel with thick iron rings holds the cool
pure water used to quench the hot metals.
"   A large forge surrounded by thick brick walls lies in the center
of the room, constantly being stoked with coal and hay to purify
or melt the different types of metal.

398.name: The Polishing Room
desc: "   In one corner of the room is a large, flat rectangular vice with a
partially sharpened sword in it.  Small slivers of curled metal litter
the floor around it, as well as a fine metallic powder.  A dark, thick
ash clings to the fixtures of this room, spilling in from the forge.  A
long oaken table lies opposite the vice, with many different polishing
and sharpening stones scattered along its surface.  Burnishing tools are
set in a box, next to polishing powders and heavy cloths.  Small emerald
bottles of clove oil rest against the wall, their sweet, cloying scent
mixing with the stale smell of the forge.
"   A large boxlike device made of fire-hardened oak and bands of iron
lies here on the ground.  Small, solid clamps hold tight a partially
sharpened sword.  The remnants of the sharpening process, small curls
of metal and metallic dust, litter the floor around the vice.

399.name: A Tranquil Room
desc: "   Small, well placed angular cuts in the wall keep this room
well ventilated and cool.  Dark footprints, a fine mixture of
ash and metal, mark the floor leading back to the adjacent forge.
A simple, unadorned bed and table are the only furnishings in the
room.  On the table are a few books and a small ceramic bowl of
clear water, with a worn and ragged towel next to it.
"   On the table are books of formulas and compositions for different
qualities of various metals used for forging, and their resulting
application for use as weapons.

400.name: The Supply Room
desc: "   Numerous piles of neatly stacked ingots of various types of
metal lie in thick, even lines against the wall.  The pale light
from the forge gleams gently off the ingots, showing off the vast
range of differing metals: from the dark gray of iron, to the
bright shine of mithril, and even to the black, light-absorbing
adamantite.  Large copper buckets line the wall near the ingots,
filled to the brim with all manner of different ores awaiting the
smelting and purification process.  Sand molds for different types
of weapons lie on a wooden table, near a large bin of coal for the
forge.  Off to one side of the room are tightly packed bales of hay
and numerous small ceramic urns of mud.
"   Many heavy ingots of various metals are stacked in neat piles
against the wall. Flickering light from the forge glints off of
the many different colors of metal.

501.name: Outside the Inner Gate
desc: "   You are standing outside the gate leading to the inner city.  The gate
does not appear to work any more.  The great wooden doors are held back
and at their base lies merchandise and a few beggars with their bowls
held out.  From here you can see the new city wall to the east and it's
great gate.  To the north and south the smaller older inner wall stretches
north and south, hiding the inner city.

502.name: Outside Tiernan's Stables
desc: "   You are standing outside a range of stables, the most prominent being
Tiernan's of Endar.  The smell of manure and the sound of horses is
unmistakeable.  Many of the folk passing by cover their faces to avoid
the smell.  You can enter the stables through a large gate.  To the west
and east you see the great eastern gates of Midgard, both new and old.

503.name: A Large Modern Thoroughfare
desc: "   You are standing to one side of a large thoroughfare.  The street looks
newly laid with fresh flagstones and lamps along each side.  To the east
you can see a gate leading through the inner wall to the city inside.
The wall hides most of the city with only the pinnacle of the ivory tower
visible from this point.  To the west you can see another gate, a larger one,
leading through the outer wall.  To your north you can see the garden pathway
to the Crimson Clover Inn and Tiernan's Stables.

504.name: West Wall Crossroads
desc: "   You are standing just inside the outer city wall, you can see the great
gate that guards the entrance to the city.  There are small alleys leading
both north and south.  There seems to be a small group of people to the
south and another such group further north, and of course there are the
few drunks that can always be found around pubs and city gates.  You can
see the remains of a signpost, broken at the base.  There is a very strong
smell of horse manure from the many stables nearby.
"  All you can see is the stump of a signpost, it is obviously new, quickly
vandalised and never repaired.

505.name: The City Gate
desc: "   You are standing under the arch of the city gates.  The porticullus is
down and rusted solid into place.  The gate itself is splittered iron-word,
enough holes to see the peaceful forest outside, but no chance of escape.
There is a gatekeeper but he seems to be a little bit too fond of the precious
liquid, and is gentle snoring in a corner.  It is damp and chilly under this
arch, and there is a pungent smell, reminding you of other less savoury places.
There is a door leading into the gatehouse.

506.name: Outside the Western Entrance to Midgard
desc: "   You are standing outside the city gate.  The gates are partially shut,
keeping out the strong wind of the plains from sweeping through the city.
The great city wall stretches to the north and south.  Looking outward
from the city there lies the great plain, leading to the great plains and
forests to the west of the city.  The road looks very dusty, making your
mouth dry and parched at sight of it.

507.name: Above the City Gate
desc: "   You are standing above the city gate, the gate is closable in case
of trouble and at night, you can see the mighty gears and cables that
currently hold the gate open, you can see from here that the gate is
balanced perfectly, a single person could close this gate, and once
locked, a horde would not be able to reopen it.

508.name: On the Western Wall
desc: "   You are on the wall that bounds the city on the west.  Looking
back over the city you can see the skyline of the city, the mages'
towers, the two great cathedrals, and the sundry buildings of the
city.  Looking down, just inside the wall there is a laneway running
parallel to the wall and you can see a number of stables for horses
nearby.  On the other side of the wall you can see the forests in
the distance. To the south you can see the entrance to the gatehouse.

509.name: On the Western Wall
desc: "   You are on the wall that bounds the city on the west.  The wall
is almost a proper road in width, wide enough for three men abreast.
There are two walls on either side of the path, a small one for safety
on the inside and a thick wall, two feet thick at least facing out.
Looking up and down the wall you can see the guards patrolling in a
regular pattern.

510.name: On the Western Wall
desc: "   You are on the outer city wall.  The wall is almost a proper road
in width, wide enough for three men abreast.  From here you can see
the great forests to the east.  Inside the wall, between the new and
old city walls you can see the elven quarter, with the light wooden
buildings and narrow streets.

511.name: On the Western Wall
desc: "   You are on the wall that bounds the city on the west.  The wall
is almost a proper road in width, wide enough for three men abreast.
From here you can see the great forests to the east.  Inside the
wall, between the new and old city walls you can see the elven quarter,
with the light wooden buildings and narrow streets.  Beyond that you
can see the great golden dome of the cathedral.  To the north you
can see the entrance to a turret tower with racks of equipment
at its entrance.

512.name: On the Western Wall
desc: "   You are on the wall that bounds the city on the west. To the north
is the entrance to the tower.  You can see great racks of equipment
along the turret wall.  From here the turret blocks the view north
but inside the city you can see the elven quarter and in the distance
the ivory tower.

513.name: Turret Guard Room
desc: "   You are standing in the guardroom of a large turret.  Around you
can see two doors leading out to the city walls.  The room is filled
with benches and chairs for the guards and a large fire crackles in
the grate.  There are a few guards present here checking their weapons
and armour.

514.name: On top of the Turret
desc: "   You are standing on top of the guard tower.  From here you have an
excellent view of the world outside the city, to the north you can see
the cold icy wastes and to the west the great forests start but a short
distance from the city walls.  Looking in toward the city, you can see
the towers and castles in the centre with odd splashes of green from the
few parks.  You can also see the poor and rich sections of the city.
Looking between the new and old city walls, you can see some of the
houses that have built up outside the city as space was used up within
the city.  The elven population have built their own section to the
south and to the east lie a myriad of houses of different shapes
and sizes, leading up and past the great cathedral.

519.name: Above the City Gate
desc: "   You are standing above the city gate, the gate is closable in case
of trouble, you can see the mighty gears and cables that currently
hold the gate open, you can see from here that the gate is balanced
perfectly, a single person could close this gate, and once locked, a
