horde would not be able to reopen it.  On either side of the room
you can see exits leading out onto the walls.

520.name: In front of the Northern Gate
desc: "   You are in front of a large gate in the northern wall of the city.
There are two newly constructed towers on either side of the gate.  The
gate has been firmly sealed, it's blackened with fire and splintered with
axes, but it's definitely not going to be opening anytime soon.
There are some guards looking out from the guardhouses, they seem wary
and suspicious, and seeing the dodgy characters on the streets, it's probably
very understandable. Slightly to the south of the gate there is a small bridge,
crossing an open sewer which leads in an east-west direction, flowing westward
and out of sight.

521.name: Outside the Northern Gate
desc: "   You outside of the northern gate of the city.  To the north you can
see a large moor with a castle on the distant horizon.  There is a faint
mist covering the moor, tendrils of which reach southward to the city.
The gate itself looks recently built, with some scaffolding visible over
the wall.  The rough grey stone of the outer wall looks unbroken and
still capable of withstanding assault.

522.name: Near the City Wall
desc: "   You are near the city wall.  There is a lot of construction work,
it seems as if there are watchtowers being built and guardposts, and
some work on demolishing the wall, perhaps a new gate is being built.
To the south you can see the great cathedral with its golden dome rising
over the roof-tops.

523.name: Along A Wide Road
desc: "   You are in the middle of a wide road.  There are several fine buildings
on either side of the road, and several that are still in construction.
To the north you can see the city wall and some large towers half-built.
To the south you can see the road pass through a small alley and the
cathedral in the distance.

524.name: Along A Wide Road
desc: "   You are in the middle of a wide road.  The pavement slabs seem newly
laid, without any of the ruts of normal roads.  There is a large building
off to the east of the road.  It extends to the back of the cathedral
and has an impressive entrance.  On the opposite side of the road there
is another tall building with some words inscribed over the entrance.

525.name: Along A Wide Road
desc: "   You are standing in a newly crafted alley along the east side of the
cathedral.  The cathedral in its beauty and aura makes you feel safe
and at peace.  To the north you can see that the road leads to the
city walls where there is a lot of construction work.  Many of the
buildings on either side of the road seem new but the hustle and bustle
that you can see to the south is quietened considerably by the various
guildhouses and the Cathedral between.

526.name: In a small alley
desc: "   You are standing in a newly crafted alley along the east side of the
cathedral.  The cathedral in its beauty and aura makes you feel safe
and at peace.  To the south you can see a large gate and to the east the
training ground of the Paladins Guildhouse and the large numbers of
trainees.  The road north leads into a large alley, with several impressive
buildings along both sides.  To the south you can see through a large gate
the road leading to the central plaza.

531.name: Turret Guard Room
desc: "   You are standing in the guardroom of a large turret.  Around you
can see two doors leading out to the city walls.  The room is filled
with benches and chairs for the guards and a large fire crackles in
the grate.  There are a few guards present here checking their weapons
and armour.

532.name: On top of the Turret
desc: "   You are standing on top of the guard tower.  From here you have an
excellent view of the world outside the city, to the north you can see
the cold icy wastes and to the east the forests form a dark green base
to the grey mountains in the distance.  Looking in toward the city,
you can see the city graveyard beneath you.  It extends almost all
the way to the cathedral to the west and the palatial structures to
the south.  Beyond the graveyard and inside the inner wall you can
just make out some of the greenery of the city park.

542.name: Turret Guard Room
desc: "   You are standing in the guardroom of a large turret.  Around you
can see two doors leading out to the city walls.  The room is filled
with benches and chairs for the guards and a large fire crackles in
the grate.  There are a few guards present here checking their weapons
and armour. The sound of water splashing against the walls is
continuous.

543.name: On top of the Turret
desc: "   You are standing on top of the guard tower.  From here you have an
excellent view of the world.  Inside the city you can see a dark
moody building which all know to be the Cathedral of the Dark and to
the east the shipyards.  Nearer to the wall the poor of the city
seem to have gathered with slum like buildings clutching together
for safety, leaving only the smallest of alleys between them.  Looking
outward you can see the great plains to the sound with the lake to the
southeast with forests to the west.

544.name: The Outer City Gate
desc: "   You are standing under the arch of the city gates.  The porticullus is
hanging askew but still firmly blocking the way.  The gate-house itself is
falling apart, with granite stone-work lying about, fallen from the roof.
There may once have been a gate-keeper, perhaps now the gently swaying
skeleton swinging from one part of the porticullus.  The stonework here
has been burnt with an unusually hot fire.  There is a door leading
into the gatehouse.

545.name: The New Eastern Way
desc: "   You are standing to one side of a new road.  The traffic
is quite heavy with a mixture of carts and pedestrians. Behind
you is a long wrought iron railing, painted in black, which
seperates the road from the city cemetery.  From here it looks
well maintained.  The entrace to the cemetery is nearby, an imposing
iron gate, wide enough for two carriages to pass side by side.

546.name: The New Eastern Way
desc: "   You are standing to one side of a new road.  The traffic
is quite heavy with a mixture of carts and pedestrians. Behind
you is a long wrought iron railing, painted in black, which
seperates the road from the city cemetery.  From here it looks
well maintained.  In front of you is an imposing structure, shaped
partially like a castle but no entrace is visible from here.

547.name: Outside the Inner East Gate
desc: "   You are standing outside the gate leading into the inner
city of Midgard.  The gate is quite imposing and well guarded
and every person passing is checked before being let through.
On the side of the wall there is a note indicating the times
when the gate is open and closed.  To the west you can see
the outer city gate.  The road leading to the gate is bounded
to the north by the city cemetery and to the south by an imposing
castle.  A road leads south towards the Orc Quarter.

548.name: CITY GATE
desc: "   You stand on the outskirts of a large city - Midgard; the capital of this
land. The road leads east into the peace and quiet - and dangers - of the
forest; and to the west it becomes the main street of the town; surrounded by
a confusion of shops, bars, and market places.

561.name: A Dark Alley Near the Gatehouse
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking west you can see
the street as it passes the gatehouse in the wall.  The street looks
distinctly dodgy and dubious to the west and on the far side of the
road, the other alley does not inspire hope either.

562.name: A Dark Alley
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking far west you can see
the street as it enters the gatehouse in the wall.  Looking south
all you can see the golden dome of the great cathedral and some dark
pillars far to the east.  The houses look less expensive the further away
from Main Street you go.  It is damp and dirty along this path, there is
a foul smell permeating the air, a small open sewer gurgles along the
base of the wall.  You can see a small grating in the sewer leading down
into the wall, it looks very slimey, the sewer water flows through it,
with all the rubbish being blocked.  It is clearly not cleaned very often.

563.name: Along a Dirty Alley
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking west you can see
the street as it passes the gatehouse in the wall. The houses look
less expensive the further west you go. It is damp and dirty along this
path, it smells as it several of the inns customers used the shadow
of the wall for toiletry purposes.

564.name: Along a Dirty Alley
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking far west you can see
the street as it enters the gatehouse in the wall.  Looking south
all you can see the golden dome of the great cathedral and some dark
pillars just to the south- east.  The houses look less expensive the
further away from Main Street you go.  It is damp and dirty along this
path, there is a foul smell permeating the air, a small open sewer
gurgles along the base of the wall.  You can see a small grating in the
sewer leading down into the wall, it looks very slimey, the sewer water
flows through it, with all the rubbish being blocked.  It is clearly
not cleaned very often.

565.name: Along a Dirty Alley
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking west you can see the
main street as it enters the gatehouse in the wall.  It is damp and
dirty along this path, there is a foul smell permeating the air, a small
open sewer gurgles along the base of the wall.

566.name: Outside the Cathedral
desc: "   You are walking along the city wall, it overshadows you as it
towers over a hundred feet above you, looking far west you can see
the street as it enters the gatehouse in the wall.  Looking south
all you can see the golden dome of the great cathedral and some dark
pillars just to the south- east.  The houses look less expensive the
further away from Main Street you go.  It is damp and dirty along this
path, there is a foul smell permeating the air, a small open sewer
gurgles along the base of the wall.

567.name: EAST OF MIDGARD GATE
567.desc: temporary exit east to 15000, replace this room with 15000

568.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing at one side of a wide road.  To the north you
can see the road merging with another road outside of the city
gate.  To the south you can see another junction.  From here your
view is quite restricted by the great wall that runs along the
western edge of the road.  On the other side of the road though
you can see a large castle-like structure.

569.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing at a junction with Westend Lane and Redferne's
Alley.  To the east you can the alley lead towards the entrance of
a large home.  The quality of the road is excellent here, large
paving slabs of granite are tightly fitted together so that not
even a blade of grass can grow between them.  To the south you can
see the road stretch off in the distance.

570.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing at one side of a wide road.  To the north you
can see the road merging with another road. From here your
view is quite restricted by the great wall that runs along the
western edge of the road.  To the northeast you can see a large
castle, visible over its boundary walls.  There are similar
boundary walls running to the south.

571.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing in between two large walls.  The wall to the
west is the old city wall and the eastern wall is the boundary
wall for an enclosed section of the city.  The two walls reach
high over the road and block out most light, leaving it dark
and a little musty.

572.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are on Westend Lane, near the Orcish Enclave.  This enclave
has solid granite walls surrounding it.  The effect of the walls
on each side of this road is to give it a narrow feel and the
lack of sunlight makes it feel cold and damp.

573.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing in between two large walls.  The wall to the
west is the old city wall and the eastern wall is the boundary
wall for an enclosed section of the city where the orcish people
live.  The enclave wall is too tall for you to make any of the
buildings or activities inside.  To the south you can see
a junction in the road.

574.name: Redferne's Alley
desc: "   You are standing in a narrow laneway.  There seems to be a lot of warriors
on this street.  To the north, over a tall wall you can see the outskirts of
a tall castle-like building.  The entrance to the building lies to the east.
To the west you can see the old city wall and a roadway that follows it north
and south.

575.name: Redferne's Alley
desc: "   You are standing in a narrow laneway.  Before you there is a large heavy
iron-wrough door.  There is a constant flow of people through the door.
This is a very heavy door though it must be well balanced as it seems to
swing open easily for people to pass.  To the west and east you can see
the the city walls, old and new.

576.name: Redferne's Alley
desc: "   You are standing in a narrow laneway, your back to the city wall.  There
seems to be a lot of warriors on the street.  To the north, over a tall wall
you can see the outskirts of a tall building.  The entrance to the building
lies to the west.  To the west you can see the old city wall.

577.name: West Wall Street (North)
desc: "   Construction work prevents your passage any further north from
here.

588.name: West Wall Street (South)
desc: "   You are standing in the middle of a wide laneway.  To the north
you can see the city's gate to the north and to the south the
laneway leads to a series of large houses.  To one side of the
lane you can see a large, wrought-iron gate.  The gate is open
now and through the tall stone pillars, you can see a huge expanse
of a courtyard.  Two tall towers stand at either side of the gate,
while men with crossbows in hand march back and forth over the arch
of the gate, keeping a close eye on anyone that comes within
scouting distance of it.

589.name: West Wall Street (South)
desc: "   You are standing in the middle of a wide street.  The street
stretches north and south from here though in either direction a
crossroads can be seen.  The road is newly laid with new red bricks.
The passing carraiges haven't succeeded yet in making any mark on
the road.  From here you can see how the city wall runs north and
south, making the buildings within look small and insignificant.
The street has a gentle slope towards the wall and the open gutter
that lies at the base of it.

590.name: West Wall Street (South)
desc: "   You are standing at a junction in the red-bricked road.  A smaller
road leads from the main street to the east.  From here you can see
the new outer wall and to the east, down the narrow street, the
older inner wall.  The road leading east has gutters on both sides
and you the gutters flow into a small drain under you and out into
the main drain at the wall.

591.name: West Wall Street (South)
desc: "   You are standing in the middle of a wide street.  The road is newly
laid with new red bricks and even the gutter has been kept clean.  The
street stretches north as far as you can see, past two crossroads.  To
the south the road is lost to sight but you can see the city wall bending
to the southeast.  To the southeast you can see some large buildings and
directly beside you is a large heavy wooden door.

592.name: West Wall Bridge
desc: "   You are standing in the middle of a wide bridge.  The road leads of
to the north and begins to bend to the southwest, following the city wall.
The river flows through a wide but shallow arch in the city wall.
Looking at the arch you can see thick metal poles blocking any possible
passage.  Following the flow of the river, you can see the roofs of
the malting house and hopstore is visible from over the brewery wall
There is a strong smell of hops and yeast in the air
"   The arch is about 15 foot wide and consists of three arches.
Each arch is very thick and no more than a handspan apart are
the thick iron rods that block the way.  Not only do they
block people but also it seems normal litter of the river, which
has piled up around the iron rods.

593.name: West Wall Street (South)
desc: "   You are standing at the edge of a wide road.  The road bends to the north-
west and also leads to the southeast.  Looking to the southeast you can see
the water's edge and a long expanse of city wall stretching out into the bay.
The full view to the water is blocked by some tall buildings on the city
side of the lane.  To the northeast the view is similarly restricted though
you can see that the road rises a little.

594.name: South Wall Road
desc: "   You are standing on South Wall Road, or so the sign on the wall says.  To the
northwest the sign indicates that the West Wall Road (South) may be found.
From here you cannot see much to the northwest as the road bends around tall
buildings and all that you can see is the tall wall looping around the outside
of the building.  To the east you can see the wall looping slowly to the north-
east but again visibility is limited.  The road here is a little damp here, with
the gutter running along the inside of the wall quite full.
"   There is a sign on the wall that indicates that the road you are on and to
the east is South Wall road (West) and to the northwest East Wall Road (South)
can be found.

595.name: South Wall Road
desc: "   You are sounding in the middle of a wide road.  The great city wall loops
likes a crescent to the northeast and northwest.  The buildings here are smaller
than those to the west and the gurgle of slow flowing water can be heard to the
north.

596.name: Farrell Avenue
desc: "   You are standing in a wide avenue with large granite paving slabs
on either side.  To the west you can see the city wall towering up
and a road leading both ways along it's edge.  The traffic on the
road is much greater than this quiet street.  To the east the road
stretches on and turns to the south at the end, near the inner
wall.  On either side of the road you can see fine homes, some
with their doors straight onto the streets, others behind large
walls.

597.name: Farrell Avenue
desc: "   The street is quiet with only the occassional person passing you by.
Looking up and down the street all you can see is a very well laid
red-brick road borders by granite slabs.  On each side of the road
there are fine houses and some have even guards monitoring their
entrances.  Looking further down the road you can see a city wall
in each direction.

598.name: Farrell Avenue
desc: "   You are at the corner in the street.  From here the road leads
a small distance to the south and eastward down a long street.
You are standing close to the old city wall, showing its age
with the weather-worn stone.  High above the wall, about 10 feet
above the ground level, there is a large plaque fastened to
the wall.
"   The plaque has the letters FARRELL carved into the dark rock.
Beneath the title there is an engraving depicting a man in fine
clothes with dignitaries on either side paying homage and attention
to the centre figure.  At the bottom of the engraving it says,
"Honour and Glory Forever to the First Councillor of Midgard
who Led the Great Expansion of Midgard in the year 203".

599.name: South Wall Road
desc: "   You are at a small junction in the road.  To the north you can see a group of
small buildings, cluttered together.  The road here is quite damp and the city
wall crowds out much of the light.  To the west you can see the road stretch out
towards better buildings but the view to the east is blocked.

600.name: Sea-Wall Road
desc: "   You are standing just to the southwest of a small bridge leading
over a wide river.  The city wall stretches out towards the bay from here.
You can see how the bridge crosses the river and flows into the bay,
seperating the path from the wall.  To the north and west you can see
clutters of small buildings, they do not seem to be very well maintained.
"   The guards give you a quick glance and wave you through.

602.name: Broken Road
desc: "   You are standing under the arch of the city gates.  The porticullus is
raised but the solid oaks doors of the gate are still shut against the
casual visitor.  There is a gatekeeper but he seems to be a little bit too
fond of the precious fluid, and is gentle snoring in a corner.  The gates
are closed but a small passage-way through them is open.  It is damp and
chilly under this arch, and there is a pungent smell, reminding you of
other less savoury places.  There is a door leading into the gatehouse.
The road leads north into the plains.
"	The sign reads:
Beware all you who enter!  The swamp is not for anyone without VERY
good armor and just a whole lot of hit points.
The buildings are what seem to have been ones made for the production of
siege equipment as well as hand-to-hand weapons.  Since the weakening
of the Temple of Evil, buried in the swamps, there has been little
need of such a large production of equipment.

610.name: Farrell Avenue
desc: "   You are at one end of a large street that follows the city
wall to the north.  Following the wall north you can see the
road bend to the west.  Looking west you can see a large
walled estate.  Through the slats in the gate you can see
a large courtyard.  To the south there is another group of
houses and when the wind gusts from the south you can get
a smell of the lake.

611.name: The Courtyard
desc: "   The sound of metal upon metal is almost deafening here, as grizzled
veterans in full body armor train the new guard hopefuls.  The clanging
of sword on shield reverberates almost constantly throughout the entire
courtyard.  The veterans make it look almost easy, with their fluidic
motions, parry, thrust, dodge, strike.  The veterans move with the grace
of a swan, while the younger newcomers stumble about, trying their best to
ward off their superiors.  A small buildings lies to the south, its doors
wide open.  The faint sight of sunlight glittering off steel can be seen
through the door.  To the east lies a long building, which is most likely
the sleeping quarters and barracks of the soldiers.  To the north the
courtyard narrows, and a small wooden building sits.
All of a sudden, a huge pike whistles by your ear and lands with a thud
behind you.  A rather pale looking man walks up to you, mumbles his
apologies, retrieves his weapon then runs back to the center of the
courtyard.

612.name: The Armoury
desc: "   The armoury smells of freshly stained leather, and polished metals.  A
rather large gentleman sits behind a wooden desk, he looks you up and down,
decides you are of no bother to him and continues what looks to be taking
inventory of the weapons and armor.  Most of the pieces here are obviously
for the town guard, as the royal seal of the guard is embossed on them.  A
few pieces that sit against the wall, however, have tags on them,
naming their owners and marked for repair.

613.name: The Barracks
desc: "   The town guards barracks is very neat and tidy.  All beds are made with
perfect care and attention to detail.  All sheets are tucked under the
matresses with perfect folds.  The barracks stretches in either direction for
at least fifty feet.  At each end of the barracks, the royal crest of the
town guard stands proudly and prominently mounted on a large pedestal.  The
royal crest consists of a sword, embossed onto a backing of scales.  The
words, "Strength and Justice" stand out prominently below the crest.  Two
tall bronze statues stand guard at the entrance to the barracks, both in
fighting stance, swords drawn, ready to cut down any and all intruders.
The only exit leads back out into the courtyard.

614.name: A Small Common Room
desc: "   You have entered the common room of the town guards barracks.  A few
men sit around a table, lit only by a single candle, playing a game that
you have never seen before.  Every so often one of the men will yell,
"Taresta" , then proceed to slam his hand down on the table, lift his
drinking mug to his lips, down his ale, then slam his mug back to the
table with a loud bang.  Two young looking guards stand at the door
to the courtyard, watching the men play their game with a smile on
their faces.  The common room itself is pretty bare, there are no luxuries
afforded to the men that serve their town so efficiently.  A few plain
wooden tables adorn the room, with equally plain chairs sitting
uniformly around them.

615.name: On a Narrow Bridge
desc: "   You are perched on a narrow bridge that connects the path to the
south across the sea docks of the shipyard.  The road isn't really
meant to pass this way but you can see that it is well travelled.
The hump of the bridge is to the northeast but from here you can look
at the southwestern part of the city, the tall city wall protecting
everything, the small cluttered buildings leading onto some fine houses,
and the river that flows between them, keeping the two sections
apart.  The dock to the north is empty at the moment.

616.name: On a Narrow Bridge
desc: "   You are perched on a narrow bridge that connects the path to the
wharf across the sea docks of the shipyard.  The hump of the bridge
is to the southwest, blocking the biew, but your vantage point gives
you the view of the wharf, the dark image of the Cathedral of Evil
and Chaos and also of the great bay and the two enclosing arms of the
city wall.  The docks to the north are a hive of activity with a great
ship under construction in the dock nearest you.

617.name: At a Break in the City Wall
desc: "   You are standing between the sea docks of the shipyard and
the old city wall.  A hole has been broken in the city wall to
allow for access from the wharf to the shipyard.  The new city
wall was obviously designed to take the shipyard within the
city boundaries.  To the north you can see a small laneway
and peeking over the top of the old wall you can see the spires
of a cathedral.

618.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are at the edge of the wharf, where the street has narrowed and the
buildings are storm beaten and weather worn.  All along the path you can see
lobster pots and old fishing nets piled in heaps, waiting repair.  Looking
towards the north wall the path narrows, ending at a hole in the wall.  To
the north you can see the spires of the Cathedral of Corruption.

619.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are just at the edge of the market, looking out over the harbour.
Along the wharf's edge you can see fishermen fixing their nets, and cleaning
their lobster pots.  There is the gentle sound of the boats knocking against
the wooden pier with the waves.  The sailors look busy, it seems wise not
to bother them.

620.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are just at the edge of the market, looking out over the harbour.
Along the wharf's edge you can see fishermen fixing their nets, and cleaning
their lobster pots.  There is the gentle sound of the boats knocking against
the wooden pier with the waves.

621.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are in a busy market, the hustle and bustle is near deafening.  There
is a strong reeking smell of fresh fish from the shop behind you.  To the
north you can see a tall statue, and further beyond a pub that looks very
tempting, if only the smell of fish would ever leave, this would not be a bad
place to spend a few hours.
"   You are in a busy market, the hustle and bustle is near deafening.  There
is a strong reeking smell of fresh fish from the shop behind you.  To the
north you can see a tall statue, and further beyond a pub that looks very
tempting, if only the smell of fish would ever leave, this would not be a bad
place to spend a few hours.
"   WANTED
Crystal Ring, will offer generous price
Contact me at ......
The rest has been torn off

622.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are at the eastern corner of the market, it is quieter here.  There
is a strong smell of fish from the fish shop and the leftovers from the gutted
fish.  The path east narrows as it passes by the fish market.  To the west the
wharf expands into a large market area.

623.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are at the edge of the wharf, where the street has narrowed as the
fishmarket comes close to the wharf edge.  All along the path you can see
lobster pots and old fishing nets piled in heaps, waiting repair.  There
are several small fishing boats lined up along the edge, delivering fresh
fist to the market.

624.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are between the fish market and the bay.  The market is seperated from
you by a small wooden railing.  Looking into the market, you can see the
range of aquatic delights available, large cod and trout to barrels of
shrimp and crabs.  Standing here you are surrounded by the sounds of the
fishermen, selling their fish as the bells and chains on their boats
bang together gentle in the wind and sea swell.

625.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are standing near the entrance to the open-air fishmarket.  To the
north a great canvas awning covers ice-filled trays of fish.  In the
opposite direction you can see the bay through the masts of the the
fishing boats.  The wharf continues both east and west from here,
broadening out to the east before the base of the sea wall.

626.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are just at the edge of the wharf, looking out over the harbour.
Along the wharf's edge you can see sailors working on their ships,
repairing sails, weaving ropes.  There is the gentle sound of their boats
knocking against the wooden pier with the waves.  All around you there
are many crates and boxes.  Looking at the boxes you can see that they are
awaiting collection.  Nearby you can see a small dock gate that allows ships
into the cargo area for easier loading.  From here you can see the city wall
extend from land into the bay, forming a protective arm against the roughness
of the sea.

627.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are at the eastern corner of the market, it is quieter here.  There
is a strong smell of fish from the fish shop and the leftovers from the gutted
fish.  The path west narrows as it passes by the fish market.  To the west the
wharf expands into a cargo storage area.

628.name: Wharf Storage Area
desc: "   You are at the edge of the wharf, in the cargo storage area.  To the south
you can see a small open area in the wharf for ships to unload and load
their cargoes.  There is the gentle sound of the waves knocking against
the wooden pier.  All around you there are many crates and boxes.  Looking
at the boxes you can see that they are awaiting collection.  To the south-east
you can see a small hut, fitted into the corner of the wharf and the sea-wall.

629.name: Wharf Storage Area
desc: "   You are just at the edge of the wharf, looking out over the harbour.
Along the wharf's edge you can see fishermen fixing their nets, and cleaning
their lobster pots.  There is the gentle sound of the boats knocking against
the wooden pier with the waves.  The sailors look busy, it seems wise not
to bother them.  All around you there are many crates and boxes.  Looking
at the boxes you can see that they are awaiting collection.  To the south you
can see a small dock gate that allows ships into the cargo area for easier
loading.

630.name: Shipping Office
desc: "   The sign hanging from the roof says "Shipping Office" but this place
hardly deserves the name.  You are in a small hut which just consists of
a roof over a few desks.  There is no-one here currently but you can see
timetables and schedules posted on the wall.  In one corner of the room
you can see a scantily clad picture of an elven woman.
"   The schedules are indecipherable and most seem to be dated
from years ago.
"   You are looking at a picture of a scantily clad, well endowed woman.
The sort of picture that are churned out by vagabond artists by the
dozens.

631.name: Wharf Storage Area
desc: "   You are at the near the outer city wall, where there are stacks of crates
for shipping.  To the southwest you can see a small open area in the wharf
for ships to unload and load their cargoes.  All around you there are many
crates and boxes.  To the south you can see a small hut, fitted into the
corner of the wharf and the sea-wall.

632.name: The Wharf
desc: "   You are at the eastern corner of the wharf, it is quieter here.  There
is a strong smell of fish from the fish shop and the leftovers from the gutted
fish.  To the west is the entrance to the fishmarket, and a large storage
area is to the southeast.  A narrow lane goes north from here leading back
into the city.  The splashing of the waves against the pilings of the wharf
forms a gentle background noise.

633.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are at one end of Westend Lane.  To the north it stretches
out like a tunnel, burrowing its way between the old city wall on
one side and tall buildings on the other.  To the south you can
see the broad expanse of the wharf and the bay beyond.  This is
a spot of conflicting smells, the bay, the fishmarket to the south-
west and the tannery to the east.

634.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are at the junction of Westend Lane and Tradesman Alley.
To the east you can see the road go down past a range of workshops
and factories.  Large awnings cover the road, giving it protection
against the weather.  To the north, the road stretches like a tunnel
into the distance but expands out on the wharf a little distance
south of here.

635.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing in the middle of a wide road.  To the south you
can see the road merging with another road. To the north, the road
just seems to go on forever, bordered on both sides by tall walls.
To the southeast you can see the outlines of workshops and tanneries.
The smell of the tanning process drifts over on the wind.  A strange
smell when mixed with that of the sea.

636.name: Westend Lane
desc: "   You are standing at one side of a wide road.  To the north you
can see the road merging with another road. From here your
view is quite restricted by the great wall that runs along the
western edge of the road.  To the northeast you can see a large
enclosed region and to the south you can see the bay in the distance.

637.name: Westend Alley
desc: "   You are standing at a junction with Westend Lane and Empire
Lane.  To the east you can the road go a short distance before
coming to a large entranceway.  To the north and east you can see
large walls blocking all viewing of what's inside.  To the south
you can see the wharf but between here and there is a more
industrial area, with chimneys and workshops visible.

638.name: A Small Laneway
desc: "   You are in a small laneway between the old city wall and
the shipyard to the west.  From here you cannot see past the
citywall and in the other direction all you can see are
uncompleted ships.  The road here is lined with stacks of
wood and covered wagons.  There is constant traffic feeding
the needs of the shipyards.

639.name: At the Entrance to the Yards
desc: "   You are at the entrance to the great shipyards of
Midgard.  The entrance is wide enough for two carriages
side by side.  Looking through the entrance you can see
the outline of a large ship and many workers swarming over
it.  Looking south you can just see the shipyard and then
the bay and the seawall beyond.  The rest of your view
is blocked by the height of the old city wall.

640.name: The Pier
desc: "   You are at the end of the pier, where it expands out to form a wharf
which extends along the harbour front, leading back towards the square.
The pier and wharf are crowded with stacks of chests and crates, waiting to
be moved further into the city, or onto the waiting ships.  Over the sounds
of the waves lapping against the wooden supports of the pier, you can hear
the sounds of a large number of people.  Every now and then you have to
jump out of the way as a burly sailor walks by, pushing you aside, or giving
you a leery grin.

641.name: The Pier
desc: "   You are at a relatively quiet part of the pier.     You are faraway enough
from the wharf so as not to have the bustle of the people of the city, and
the cranky old fishermen, and not so close to the pier's end, where all the
big ships and ferries dock.  The pier is actually quite wide here, well
actually as wide as anywhere else, but there are less crates stacked here.

642.name: The Pier
desc: "   You are at the end of one branch of the pier.  This is the terminal for
the ferries in Midgard, the ferryman's guild rules state that all their
ferries must dock here.  There is a great energy about this place, people
from different regions disembarking either for a short stay or perhaps to
do business.  All the new arrivals are pointed towards a board, just outside
the ticketmaster's office.  Now and then you can hear good solid sea curses,
as sailors struggle to control unruly passengers and their more unruly
luggage.
"   It is a simple board upon which the City Authorities post notices to
inform travellers new to the city of the laws and regulations.  There are
several posters on the board, some old and yellowing, though a new one is
firmly posted to the board.
"   To all new visitors to our fair City
We wish to inform you that in Midgard we do not accept or allow any
rowdy behaviour, that includes drunkedness, theft, or attacking our
fine citizens.  If any person, irrespective of class or race, is
found by one of our guards to be so engaged, punishment will be
delivered immediately, at the discretion of the guard in question,
usually death.  Their decisions will not be subject to appeal.
We hope you have a pleasant stay,
City Authorities

643.name: Tradesmen Alley
desc: "   You are in a small alleyway which is covered over by large
cloth awnings.  The awning protects the tradesmen's products
from the elements.  Along the street you can see leather products,
swords, armour, dresses and jewelery shops, all displaying their
wares for the passer by.  To the west the alley leads on to the
main Western Lane.

644.name: Tradesmen Alley
desc: "   You are in a small covered alleyway which is filled with the
produts of the various tradesmen.  At this point in the street
there is a prominent armour shop, Talamark's Armour.

645.name: Tradesmen Alley
desc: "   You are at one end of a very busy alley.  The alley is covered
by a large awning, keeping the wind and rain away from the products
below.  All the products required for a modern city are available,
weapons, armour, dresses, clothes.  Behind you is the famous weapons
shop, Darlaks.

646.name: Empire Lane
desc: "   You are in a wide lane which has been very well maintained.
The lane is walled on either side but you can see a road junction
to the west.   There is an entrance arch to the east which leads
into the enclosed section to the north of you.

647.name: Empire Lane
desc: "   You are in a wide lane which has been very well maintained.
The lane is walled on either side but you can see a road junction
to the west.   There is an entrance arch here that leads into the
Orc Quarter of the city.  It is probably this reason that the
road is called Empire Lane.  From here you cannot make out any
of the details of what is inside the quarter.

649.name: On the Gangplank
desc: "   Seagulls call and circle overhead. A small schooner sits at dock
before you.  A well worn plaque can be seen attached to the bow.
The warm salty smell abounds from the sea as the ship rocks restlessly
pulling at its moorings.  The oft used gangplank stretches from the
dock to the ship here.  Sailors can be heard swearing and seen moving
about the rigging and deck as though preparing for a journey to sea.

extra.desc: A well worn and polished plaque on the bow reads The Reaper.

650.name: Along the Starboard Side
desc: "   A piece of the railing swings in here making room for the
gang plank.  Though in good repair the railing is in need of
fresh paint.  The moorings that hold the ship when docked are
tied off here and a hoist for lowering the longboat can be seen
to your left.

651.name: Before the Mast
desc: "   A tall mast rises out of the hull here.  Rigging and belaying
pins make it easy to climb to the crow's nest.  The captain's
cabin can be seen just to the east beneath the aftcastle.  To
the north lies the starboard rail from which the long boats are
launched.

653.name: Along the Port Railing
desc: "   The waves lap at the side of the boat making her rock in
the restless water.  The rail has been repaired many times
and is in dire need of new paint.  A bucket and mop sit
idle waiting to be used in swabbing the deck.

654.name: The Forecastle
desc: "   The bowsprit juts forward from the ship its sail tied down while
front rail.  A large ballista is covered by a tarp ready for when
the pirates raid another ship.  A small trapdoor leads down into the
hold and crew cabins.  The smell from a galley wafts up through the
grate in the trapdoor.
This large crossbow stands ready under the tarp a handfull of
harpoon sized bolts are close at hand.

655.name: The Aftcastle
desc: "   The helm can be found here the large wheel that guides the rudder
can be seen.  Buckets of wet sand lay about in case of a fire on deck.
A belaying pin in the wheel hold the rudder still while the ship is
docked.  Even with the sails down she moves in the waves pulling on
the moorings making the planks groan with a low sound.
A belaying pin is stuck through the King spoke the pilot must be off
drinking or gambling.

656.name: Climbing the Mast
desc: "   The rigging and sails are tied off to the mast making it
easier to climb.  A slight breeze tugs on the rigging making
it blow about.  The crows nest lies just above.  The water
can be seen lapping at the side of the ship from this height.

657.name: Crow's Nest
desc: "   This is the crows nest.  From here you can see for a far
distance.  Sea gulls fly and land above you and the slight
breeze makes the ship's flag snap and wave slowly.  A spy
glass can be seen attached to the boat here for the lookout
to spot reefs and other ships.
The spyglass can be tilted and turned on its base giving
a great view of the distance and water below.

658.name: The Mess Hall
desc: "   This small mess hall is occupied by a couple small tables.  The
crew come here to eat and relax when off duty.  Smell from the
galley come from under the north door.  A port hole lets a small
amount of light in during the day, and a small lantern hangs from
a hook in the ceiling for light during the night watch.
A small broken down oak table scratched beyond refinishing.  You
can vaguely make out the words Shron was here engraved on it.

659.name: The Galley
desc: "   The smell of stale yeast from years of baking hangs thick in
the air.  A small enclosed stone stove sits in the west corner.
Pots and pans hang about from the ceiling and many knives, plates,
and other utensils sit in racks along the walls.  A small table
has a few sacks of vegetables and dried beans upon it.  The east
door leads into what appears to be the hold.

660.name: The Crew's Cabin
desc: "   Many hammocks line this room.  Foot lockers under each for
the sailors personal gear are found here.  The port holes let
in some light but have shades that can be drawn at night to let
the sailors sleep better.  A small table at the back of the
cabin holds a single enclosed lantern that the crew can play
cards or knucklebones by.

661.name: The Hold
desc: "   This is the cargo hold.  Wooden crates and water barrels are
lashed down and a small section in the north has been walled off
for food storage.  Rats scurry about in the dark looking for a bit
of food.  Signs of old repairs and burnt marking of fires can be
seen in the walls and extra sail cloth and rigging lie about.

663.name: On the Gangplank
desc: "   Seagulls call and circle overhead. A small schooner sits at dock
before you.  A well worn plaque can be seen attached to the bow.
The warm salty smell abounds from the sea as the ship rocks restlessly
pulling at its moorings.  The oft used gangplank stretches from the
dock to the ship here.  Sailors can be heard swearing and seen moving
about the rigging and deck as though preparing for a journey to sea.

extra.desc: A well worn and polished plaque on the bow reads The Reaper.

664.name: The Long Boat
desc: "   The long boat is being hoisted up and the gangplank removed.
Better move quick to make it on the boat.

871.name: Tower of Passage
desc: "   You are in a large room.  There is a small elderly
man in the corner who occasionally glances up from
his book to see who's present.  From here you can
see a small door leading up to the next level of the
tower.  Every now and then you hear a quiet sound
that reminds you of clash of metal.  There is a
sign hanging on the wall.
"  Welcome to the Tower of Passage.  Through the
powers of Egwin the Warrior Mage this tower was
errected and embued with powerfull magical spells.
These spells create replicas of powerful men and
creatures from throughout the world.  Replicas
those these may be, harm they can inflict.
Passage to the next level can be obtained by
opening the locked door that is carried by the
replica.  Each level presents a tougher challenge.
If you succeed in defeating all replicas you will
be rewarded with a token of your achievement and
a valuable addition to your equipment.
Be warned death does await you in this tower.
Pick up the recall scroll that is available in
the next level and use this at any point to
escape the Tower.
"   The old man looks at you and points to the sign
and says gruffly "Read it!

872.name: The Preparation Room
desc: "   You are in a small room, there is only one
door, clearly leading up.  There are several benches
in the room, some equipment for sharpening your
blades and a reading table for any literature you
need to review.
Please junk the keys once you have used them
or else the mobs won't repop with the keys.
Thank you
Fionn

873.name: Level 1
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

874.name: Level 2
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

875.name: Level 3
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary

876.name: Level 4
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

877.name: Level 5
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There

878.name: Level 6
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

879.name: Level 7
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
leading up to the next level.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

880.name: The Final Level
desc: "   You are in a wide room with a single door
with the word EXIT over it.  The room is
bare but for the signs of past combat but
the detritus of combat seems to hang to the
walls without affecting them at all.  There
is a large circle drawn with a white boundary
in the centre of the room.

891.name: A Plain of Tall Grass
desc: "   Plains of grass dominate the landscape here. The
shifting colours of summer-green vegetation reach
out towards the horizon in all directions,
resembling that of a thick green carpet. The warming
sun has begun to rise above the horizon line, the
rays of light making the plains shift slightly towards
yellow in colour. The grass is layered where it has
been grazed by animals. Along with the arrival of the
morning, the sounds of life comes, insects hidden in
the tall grass giving of various noises, and birds
circling the morning sky.

892.name: short grass
desc: "   You are in a field of wild grass that reaches up to
your knees.  All around you are rolling hills of light
green grass with the occassional tree breaking the
monotony.

893.name: Surrounded by Trees of the Pine Forest
desc: "   The air lies still within the forest. The sun has
just risen above the horizon, causing the temperature
to raise. Morning fog covers the area of the pine
forest; a damp smell fills the air. The pine trees stand
close to each other, branches reaching up towards the
summer sky. Various paths trail of into all directions,
some smaller than others. The leafs shift in colour as
the sunrays touch them, changing the colour from deep
green to bright yellow. Birdsong echoes through the
forest, as the soft summer breeze send leafs shaking.
